content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												Now I realize my review will be just another grain of sand on the beach of Normandy that was the disaster called X Rebirth and that my voice will most likely be drowned out by the shouts and cries of those others who purchased the title alongside me. Close to countless reviews found on just about any gaming website can elucidate the extent of the problems this game presented. I just wanted to highlight some that mattered most to me. Given that it's near impossible to get a game released these days without a slew of bugs and glitches, I don't want to spend too much time focusing on those errors. That said, it is worth asking how on earth a company as established as Egosoft could have possibly thought XR was worthy of release. A few glitches here, maybe a bug or two in that feature there, sure but what they gave us was just an utter shock. And you have to imagine that at some point, they sat down during some meeting just before launch and said "well this is ready to hit the mainstream. We have a good product, a functioning product or at the very least a passable product but as we all know now, not one of those held true. NOT a one. To be frank, as consumers we have a right to expect a game to not have at least half the bugs XR had, especially in a AAA title. I'm not implying that every game released be absolutely bug free, but I equate this to gas prices. At a certain point in time, our country raises gas prices from oh, let’s say $2.00 a gallon to $4.50. Of course we're outraged but this persists for such a long time that when they finally reduce the price to $3.95, we jump for joy and hug our pets in excitement. Again, I don't expect the gas to be free, but I expect it to be reasonable. The games that have been released over the last few years are akin to charging a good $6.00/g for gas and nowhere has this been more true for me than with XR. I was so utterly frustrated doing the infamous 100 energy cell mission within the first hour of the game that my gf had to pull me away and take me to dinner to calm me down a bit but I let the game continue in hopes that my ship would find it’s way. Two and a half hours later and my freighter is still taking a sightseeing tour of whatever galaxy we're in (something I doubt I'll ever learn given the incomprehensible map system). Unfortunately, when I submitted for a refund 4-5 times, Steam laid this  as evidence against me stating I had played 20 some odd hours and therefore must have in some way approved of the product. Like most people I've spoken to or read about, the vast majority of that time was spent alt tabbed checking forums, practicing calming breaths, thinking about taking up religion again or going out to more dinners aimed at diffusing my ticking time bomb of frustration. Many others have stated this very thing in their own way and yet it shows us logging on more hours than we ever actually played. SO that all said, let’s say the Egosoft fairy waived her magic wand, which I'm sure is rife with glitches and probably using the wrong batteries and fixed every bug and glitch in the game. Know what we're left with? An glitch free POS. Look, I'm not trying to be some kind of hater. I, like everyone else tried time and again to justify the money I threw away in this game. And like some others also stated, there is the skeleton of a game buried in there somewhere, but I really did try. I have everything to gain in liking this game given the brick wall I've ran into with steam customer service. All the bugs aside, the design decisions they made in this day and age are just beyond understanding. I understand these guys are based in Germany but could they really not afford getting just one guy, ONE GUY who speaks native English on their staff to share some phrases with them that would pass off better than "Go Boil your Head" or, "Nice talking to you...NOT". Forget how utterly annoying it is that nearly every NPC is angry at you for no reason....well wait, they all appear to be over 70 years old, so maybe they're just old grouches.....that are supposedly piloting space and building empires......sigh.., forget the annoyance, if you can anyhow, but the dialogue left me embarrassed for them in some odd way.  How full of yourself and out of touch must you be? And How many times did Bernd say the word "Immersion"? Yisha, the co-pilot is by far and away on my top three list of hair pullers. Forget her really creepy incomprehensible animation, not sure if she's pooping in her ventilated space suit, is she's part arachnid, fighting the urge to eat me, or doing calisthenics. What I don't understand is why they put her there. I know others have voiced this in their own way, but here's the bottom line. She doesn't do anything. At all. She doesn't pilot, trade, she is nothing more than a permanent plot prop piece. I've tried finding the woman who did the voice acting for her without success. Perhaps that's for the best. She doesn't need career changing advice from some yankee. But oh my sweet jesus is it awful. It again, ruins the whole immersion. Poorly written dialogue, made worse by the worst voice acting. Missions requiring me to go here to pick this up, then there to drop it off, then here to pick up something else, then there to deliver it. I'm a fed ex truck in space stuck on rookie training duty. What i did find funny was how very early in the game, the crew to which Yisha belonged to paid me good money (I'm assuming its good since I haven't really had a chance to see an economy function) to keep her with me. It totally sounds like a made up excuse to get rid of her now that she's no longer on their ship. Out of the  literally 12 times I had to restart the game, that was the only thing that made me smile until I realized it was me they pawned her off on. If I could have ejected her from my latrine shoot, I would have right onto their windshield.  I mean the list goes on and on and on. The one thing everyone was really excited about, or at least most people, myself included, was walking around space stations. God what an exercise in frustration that was. Cookie cutter, with every NPC doing the same task  in the same corner. Every box and locker making the same sound and getting you stuck in the process 25% of the time. It was all just one big horrible horrible horrible experience. And they charged us $50 for it. They made a lot of money while many of us gave a significant chunk of our meagerly paychecks for something we were hoping would take our minds off our meagerly paychecks. Instead, I’m forced to face the harsh realities of just how much spending $50 on the wrong present for myself can impact my life in a negative way. I’ve since moved on but then I saw that Steam is finally allowing us to write reviews so here is me waving my hands telling anyone thinking of XR to change course, go somewhere else. Dive into an empty swimming pool and incur more enjoyment. One a last note, I emailed egosoft early on and the Bernd man himself replied. I wont bother with the details cuz he didn’t give me any. It was short, condescending, blowing off my thoughts and recommendations and still full of himself with regards to that incredibly inappropriate “We’re a Success!” message he tied onto his failing apology. In short all that said was, we failed, you bought it, and we MADE MONEY OFF YOU!!! Yay!Sigh. Hey Egosoft, if any of you ever read this, go and apologize. Not to us cuz that would take the remainder of your lives to do. Rather, apologize to every other gaming company for the bad faith you instilled in all the gamers out there that will inevitably think twice about purchasing something at launch. You screwed up the curve in the worst possible way. So to all of you that made these decisions to the ones that knew better but lacked the courage to tell those in power  what time of day it was and that they’re releasing a big failure, I say SHAME on you.

Posted: December 27, 2013
												This game just wasn't ready to be published.  After 21 patches and a month and a half after release, the game is still riddled with bugs.  I'm going to wait about 5 more months to try again as the developers are going to need that time to fix the uncountable issues with the game.  I still can't make it through the campaign without the game asking me to transport someone to some non-existent space station.  The only way people seem to make it through is by modifying the massive save files.  This game is worse than a lot of greenlight games are.  As a programmer I understand building a dynamic universe like this is extremely complex.  There are a lot of complaints about unfinished games being released to early from Battlefield 4 to Diablo 3.  Those games had some understandable problems on release.  This game however, is not even close to playable and can't even be compared to the problems other games have had on release.  I don't blame the developers, I blame the publishers for releasing a game that quite simply is not ready to be played.  I really wanted to like this game and tried really hard to looks past the glaring problems.  I really hope they succeed in fixing the issues and get the game to a playable state.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2014
												In this review I shall not criticize as too many have already wasted all of their energy at that. Instead I shall list suggestions which would make this game's experience fantastic because the original concept is indeed fantastic, but unfortunately not exploited. All I mention here is based on enough hours of playing and completing the whole campaign (thanks to the 1.24 patch).Remember that Egosoft have already invested a lot of time, money and resources for the existing content, so do not expect much improvement on this project. They might decide to release DLCs but these are not solutions to existing problems, they are extensions of existing problems.Here it goes:__________________________________________Hardware-Make the game running smooth on the average modern PCControls-Enable look around using numpad as in X3-Split roll function in two button: roll right, roll left and assignable on gamepad as in X3X Universe-Add Boron and Paranid factions (it's unfair if they come in payable DLC)-Add Pirate stations. If not directly visible give hints, indications that they might be somewhere near some zones and we'd explore for them-Make trade/missions possible with PiratesGraphics-Make MPC characters look and act more realistic-Stations/ships/objects should not be visible while outside nebula cloud-Nebula cloud should be visible from any distance while in the sector, not just from its zone.-Prevent ships going through one another or through stations as if hollowOptional but doable cool and practical graphical suggestions-Make it possible to dock in stations manually with animation of opening hangar and docking procedure (if enabled by player   in settings)-Make it possible to travel in a station from one dock/area to another using a local train or something cool -Make planetary descent possible (limited areas only if too complicated) for trade and exploration, alone or with party (yes it's possible, Evochron series have this fantastic feature with realistic atmospheric characteristics)UI and cockpit-Remove radial menu and replace with command/property menu as in X3-Add radar display-On info display, while targeting ships, add distance and velocityIn albion Skunk-Disable/modify Ysha speech “Requesting permission to dock” when docking at own ship/station or Xenon stations-Enable free walking around the cockpit when not seated-Enable Click on pilot chair to be seated while free walking around instead of the control switch in the corridor-Enable interaction functions with other tools/computers in cockpit for small routine maintenance/monitoring (engineer cannot do everything)-Enable more speech with co-pilot and crew to kill the silence and stillnessNavigation & map-Enable jump drive for Skunk: gate to gate and point to point (unfocused optional but cool)-Enable zoom in/out in map, not just press sector/zone...-Add written details on map for stations, ships and objects, not just clickable list o right side-Enable filter map content for display-Let us select our own speed in highways instead of following other crafts-Have boost consume its own energy storage, not from shield or enable upgrade like energy splitter or something-When docked in carrier/capital ship fix the “plot course” function, or provide clear instructions-Add many more systems including our solar systemStations-Give traders appropriate stores/workshops, so that trade doesn't take place in a bunk or bar-Give NPC more dialog variety and more casual-Modify Ren Otani speech: “Show me your wares please”, to something more realistic, casual and add variety, not always the same sentence (appropriate the the service in question)-Make NPC give small missions (e.g. “provide 20 units of teladianium paneling”, “ship this package at this station to this guy”...) which would affect on discounts and rep on faction.Trade-Enable more than 3 planned trading trips per ship-When more than one trade trip is planned for the same station keep the ship docked till all transactions are finished-Add button in trade menu to view/edit/delete planned trade trips in detail-Add best buy/sell software upgrade (e.g. MK1 limited to sector, MK2 limited to system, MK3 for whole map)-Add many more upgrades for the SkunkShipyards-Enable command ship (all but Skunk) to go to selected shipyard for repair/upgrade without having to go there yourself first (with command menu X3 style this would be possible)-Enable purchase of fighters (if there are I must be blind) to use them as wingsCombat-Enable “Lock on Target”: when selecting a target it should be possible to press lock on target to stay locked on that target till it is destroyed or out of scanner range or you manually select another target. It should also be configurable in settings-Don't make enemy fighters stick so close to station like flies on a light bulb__________________________________________Some details might have slipped my mind, however, feel free to add or modify this list. I believe we should put as much pressure as possible on Egosoft on this cause it's really a waste. They really can make a master piece if they want as they've already done an amaising job with the X3 series, they just needed to improve on those.

												Do NOT buy this game.Still seeking refund. I've spent more time trying to fix this game and tweak it to just get it running than actually trying to play it. Extremely let down. Pre-ordered a lemon. Looking back on the other X series games I have played, this game will definitely not get fixed up to spec anytime soon. There are still bugs with their other games that the community had to create fixes for (through modding). This game is beyond and kind of patch.Despite how ugly and badly designed the game is, if you can even get it to run, or continue running without crashing every other couple of minutes, my hats off to you. Do not purchase this game. Even if it goes on some holiday sale for 75% off, it will end up eating most of your time trying to work around things. The trading system and other elements in the game that are main features are bugged or not working properly. It was unplayable. On a high end rig, this game runs like doo-doo. After one of the most recent patches, it actually dropped my fps in stations and made things even more unresponsive. Gave me a headache. Alt-f4.Horrible.Don't believe me? ==>>                                                   http://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/x-rebirthI'm a big fan of the previous games, especially the X3:TC and X3:AP titles. I've played the hell out of them and they were awesome. I have games in the series in and out of steam. This game is unplayable, buggy, dumbed down, poorly designed UI, bad AI (still), poor optimization for PC, way too expensive for what it is, unresponsive, extremely poor fps on a wide range of PC's to the point of making it unplayable, and has made the steam forum so congested with bad reviews/complaints that you cannot even find workarounds for bugs that the community  might have solved on their own. There are so many problems with the game that they can't be listed. Heck, the devs have a pinned topic on their forum with a list of current bugs and other things that are game breakers which span over two pages long.Bottom line:================Do not buy this game.================

content:
Posted: December 7, 2013
												Never has a game been so beautiful, so deep, so luxurious in detail, and yet so boring.Sometimes people hold up Elder Scrolls II: Daggerfall as an example of an amazing game with so much scope. It has the biggest game map EVER. The entire continent is created, thousands of cities and villages, 750,000 npcs. Yet for all of this, it feels completely empty. Why? Because there is no soul there. Everything is fairly barebones, most of it is cut and pasted from one point to another. You enter a red building at one end of the world and find a +1 dagger, then go across the continent to another city in another entire other race's kingdom, go into a red building and find the same dagger. This is a bit of an over-simplification, but X-Rebirth suffers from this same downfall. It's beautiful, has a lot of options, and yet feels entirely sterile and without a soul. It doesn't help the game has a kinda meh combat system either.

content:
Posted: March 16, 2015
												Game is pretty darn good and stable, even with alt-tabbing repeatedly like i did while writing this review. Cockpit detail is far better than previous incarnations. You can partially swivel to look around inside the cockpit very smoothly. External view is fully rotatable and zoomable plus there is a tactical view (edit: well not really; it's a close-up view of the enemy, useful for identifying Beyond Visual Range enemies so that you don't bite more than you can chew) There is also a built-in game recorder just to mention. Space stations scale is humongous, they are also very detailed. Because of the gigantic scale of the space-stations, landing and taking-off has an added sense of immersion.Trading items are expanded over previous Xs as there seems to be many miscellaneous non-functional items whose only purpose seem to be just to add content (edit: for trading purposes) BUT addition of items also added a new feature; crafting. Crafting allows the forming of new higher value items or special purpose items, like gifts or hacking tools. Incidentally nearly everything is tradeable, ship equipment, missiles, even the marines. The one thing that isn't is the cockpit configurations; it's an expense. If you don't like the cockpit layout you can buy a different one. There's no functional difference in gameplay; just a visual preference. Not sure if crew is tradeable though, 'coz i might want to trade my co-pilot for a more ...erm interesting conversationalist.Finding the best prices is not difficult, even in the beginning, it's only a bit tedious as it requires repetitious page flipping between the various vendors offers. You can fly to the vendor to make the trade if they are not in the same station or you can simply use the menu but there is a shuttle fee for the extra convenience. It's quite easy to make money once the trading interface is fully understood. You can be a smuggler dealing in contraband or be a smuggler simply because you don't have the licence to deal in restricted goods. Licences can be purchased provided you meet the minimum faction rating.Game is completely open-world and non-linear even in the campaign mode just like Freelancer but it does it much better as the economy is dynamic and affected by cargo ships moving throughout the universe (like Space Rangers). Can't comment about the story though as i've barely begun the story missions.NPC: Pilot, come and get some bargains from me.Player: Show me your wares please.NPC: Sure lets get to it.NPC: Can i show you anything else? And i mean... anything. ;-)NPC: You all have a nice day.So far the one thing that is so annoying about this game is the bar music or is it music in a bar? No regrets with this one, game is soo good, i couldn't wait for 75% off like always. Music in space though is awesome; one of the strongest reasons i couldn't wait to add it to my collection.Generic NPC monologue is limited and therefore repetitious but that is a minor fault. Nothing like the dynamic dialog between NPCs in Fallout 2 or in more recent games like Skyrim.There are no minigames; if those arcade machines you see in the bar can be operated by credit tokens, that would be it. What seems like a minigame - small talk is but an option during interaction with NPCs in the stations. It's a useful, easy and fast way to increase faction rating in addition to trading and destroying pirates. High faction ratings mean better discounts.Perhaps the single biggest advantage this game offers over previous Xs is the option to save the game at any time, free without the need to buy salvage insurance, even in space like in the middle of trying to capture a capital ship or in a bar, when the NPC starts talking. It's a very useful nifty feature that helps you backtrack to rectify a colossal mistake, i mean who doesn't like an on demand savegame feature right? Incidentally you have up to 10 save slots in addition to a quicksave slot and 3 autosave slots making a total of 14 slots. Be warned, the savegames are quite big, when all slots are used it can reach about 500 MB or more. Too many games rely on a single savegame or worse a single autosave. IMO it's disrespectful to deny PC gamers multiple save slots, i mean it's a PC game not a console game. Here we have the best of both worlds; good old school multiple saves and autosaves.Highly recommended if you can get past the little niggles. 8/10

content:
Posted: May 13, 2015
												I'm an X vet. X Rebirth is NOT X3, just leave that thought else where. X Rebirth is a new direction on the X Universe.There are many differences good and bad and some concepts are implemented a bit more simpler and some are far more complex.You take the role of a single ship captain and view the universe from one perspective.I think the latest version is extremely enjoyable, 3.53, far more so with use of Mods. If you loved the role of playing statistical manager from the safety of a itemized data screen then this game is not for you. The ability to directly control mass ships via a remote display map screen in X3 is not as easily, or not at all the same in Rebirth. Think of it as traveling through the universe in a single ship with emphasis on what is in front of you.As a FPSS (first person shooter ship) this game is a whole hell of a lot of fun. It is easy to organize fighter squads under your wing and with a click order them to attack a target. This aspect of the game is wonderful. Drones, missiles, and underlings are your path to survival.Again look at it from a single point character as you fly the Albion Pride influencing the universe as you go. You can personalize the cockpit, or mod your own!, to make your ship more to your own liking.For Trading I think it is far more satisfying than previous games. No, you can't personally captain the largest freighter in the universe. What you can do is have freighters in your squad and as you fly through the universe quickly assign them trade jobs. This is even made easier with trade software and you can do this all from a menu screen. Give a single freighter 4 or 5 trade jobs and go do something else, or dock on that trade ship and watch the action from the bridge. You are not the captain, you are the Admiral, and Admirals don't drive, they command. The campaign I find enjoyable. Much more simplistic than many missions in X3 but it serves as an excellent Tutorial which was greatly missed in prior X games. If you find yourself starting to see the short failings of certain aspects of the game CONGRATULATIONS you've made it further in this game than most do in the previous X3 games :PWith that said, no, Rebirth does not have the same Universe longevity as say X3 TC. You will hit that end game moment a bit sooner and find less to do, at least at the moment. Then again the X series has always been about what you make of it, so try something new, or mod.In ending, yes I can now recommend X Rebirth as the game is excellent and becoming better and better each official release with amazing mods to make the universe remarkable. Has it overcome X3 TC/AP ? not quite, but it's damn close.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
												First off, Get it, I think you will like it a lot epecially as its not nearly as expensive or load intensive as Eve Online or Star Trek...If you're new to the modability of the X universe you probably don't know this but, the X3 universe had great components to it.  It still had profound limitations that the raw Vanilla or un-moded program had that confined what a mod script could actually do.  Like you couldn't make the text size bigger very easily... Why?  To many conflictual errors that bleed into other scripts.  I imagine that XRebirth will still have parts that a mod can not change and will have to come down the pipe later from the dev's.  For this reason, I will add all my comments as I have played with about 80-90 mods installed right now.Pro's GRAPHICS:  See system info at bottom of review.- This is a very immersive space sim, much more so than X3, and most other space sims ever could be.  - It's visually astounding in many ways w/(ULTRA SETTINGS) and I love that you can not only pilot ships but that you can move around them.  - I can't say anthing has seemed "glitchy", produced atrifacts, or caused the texture panels to split when you are close to them at just the right angle like a lot of open world games have issues with.  It's refreshing in that arena for sure.  SHIP/STATION DYNAMICS:- Stations are vastly more complex, beautiful, and formitable in combat.  - The change from weapon "energy usage p/sec" to "over heating" is and interesting componnent that makes combat more user skill dependent and less "cookie cutter" when piloting fully out-fitted ships.  - In the "skunk", M6 Corvette class, your 5 main assult weapons have their own unique applications and it makes for some more realism.  Sometimes I'd switch to the wrong weapon and well, if I were a space pirate, in the heat of battle, I might just do that so.... again... more immersiveness.- Sheilds, Engines, and Weapons can also be modified to fit your play style, tanky high sustainability, high damage dealing but overheats quickly, agile and fast shotting or a mix of all.- Combat, especially with regard to capital ships is much better.  You can target individual weapons turrets, engines, and other ship components like radar to help ensure boarding opperations.- Boarding opperations are also much more complex allowing you to disable engines and weapons before capturing.- The addition of diverse and specialized crew holds a lot of promise as well.- Drone piloting is much more fluid and clear.  In X3 I had very little idea when or what they were doing.- Scanner functions and Hacking give a modicum of chance regarding profiterring,treasure hunting, and sabotage.GAME PLAY:- The story line seems decent and the missions that are available have greater realism.  - I have only logged about 35+ hrs but, have found it to be very fun and awe-inspiring.- There are many worth while mods now that give the game greater depth, character, ease of interface, diversity, and fluidity.- Most of the Vanilla music while flying is great at setting more immersive ambiance.Neutal's - Having to scan all the parts of a station is tedious for sure.  But, they look so cool!  My favorite is the one with the mono-rail train transporting on top of it!  They have unique sounds and characteristics that make the whole floating in space to investigate much more cool and worth the time invested.- The addition of so many craftable items is interesting but, how does all that stuff not take up cargo space??- Saved game and startup load times are substantially longer... maybe its time I got a SSD...lolCon'sGAME PLAY:To a large Extent the videos add depth to the main plot missions but they are overall lacking in orginality.  I think more will come through mods... we will see.SHIP/STATION DYNAMICS:- The highways and station scanning are interesting components.  Unfotuanatly, they necessitate "no collissions" being instituted.  Infinitely bouncing off stuff with speed and size of objects being completely irrelevent, is gimmicky to say the least.  It does distill the immersive experiance substantially. - Where are the Boron??  They had some pretty cool ships.  Especially with the "living hulls" mod...- There do not seem to be very many ships in this version of the X universe yet.  There is some diversity among races still but a lot of bleed over.  As in, multiple factions if not all use the same sets of ships...  maybe more comming??  Its been 2 years or more already...- - - What happend to having "Wings" with different color codes?- THE CREW INTERFACE:- Needs a lot of work.  - I don't see how you can "lockout" the ability to command a MORE experienced but not full 5 stared engineer on your M6 from commensing 100% hull repairs and need to dock somewhere to use another, LESS experienced engineer...do they have access to full schmatics or something??- The inability to command your docked ships crew at all when on a station is just stupid.  That needs to change.  Com Badge??- The "Property Menu" was much better organized and complete in X3.  Now, it doesn't show your personel at all, even though you have so many more types of them... why?  - - What would it take to be able to move piolts around??  Now, your pilot gets sold with the ship??  That is annoying...- - Setting up a squad and quickly initiating commands has always been a problem in the Vanilla versions but this takes it to a whole new level.  I have spent way too much time trying to figure out why I couldn't give commands to a secondary squad or crew memeber and only through the "details" menu under that persons info...  Too many levels deep.  What about a similar interface to drone selection?- Why are your bargans with particular traders only good for that visit??  Too much to load and remember?  I don't like having to do the more complex conversation stuff through the psudo-dice-rolling-manipulation-interface-thing everytime I wan't a deal.  Especially with the 1-2 minute load times when mistakes are made..HACKING: - If you are going to hack something, you should have choices.  I DO think it should be bouned to what a console can do but NOT in such that its just a general "Hack"  that gets the pre-destined result...I'd like something like, I'm in, now what can I do, how much time can I stay in?Having written this little book, a good number of the cons will probably be changed through mods.  Those that can't be will hopefully grab the attention of the Devs to focus on for updates.  They have already come a long way since its launch and I'm very happy to pay for this version of the game so far.Sys info:MB- Gigabyte GA-890FXA-UD5 v2.1 w/s7e Bios Flash for AMD FX chipsCPU- AMD FX8300 overclocked to 4480ghz... stable and coolGPU- EVGA Nivida GTX 960 stock speedsMEM- 2x 8gb Gskill Aires 21300 @ 1866mhz, low latancy, dual channeledHD- 4x Hitachi 7200rpm 500gb in RAID 10PWR- 750w Antexall quietly air cooled in a CoolerMaster HAF case

												[This review is based on "impressions", being edited and updated conform I play.]• First Impression Review:Even with a lot of bad reviews, I watched some videos and liked what I saw, and the 3.X updates convinced me. First I started playing with a Xbox gamepad, and had to select it on options menu to be auto recognized. Despite all the game being accessible, I didn't liked the ship navigation, so I dropped the gamepad and started configuring my Logitech Extreme 3D Pro + Razer Tartarus to play with every assist off and Hard difficulty.Configure all the menus, options, interactions and shortcuts was very hard, because I didn't knew what those things do, and after 7 hours I still don't know what is everything. The movements was the most easy part, common to any plane/ship game.Enter inside stations is fun, see your crew in your ship too. Talk to people is interesting, because some of the same professions have different things to say. I entered in a bar with music and I loved the ambientation. I saw an alien guy there for the first time.Navigate is amazing. Around the stations the activity is intense, and sometimes the cops scan my ship and thanks me for the cooperation. The combat with joystick offer a good challenge and I lost a ship already, because while I was trying catch one enemy, the other was burning my crew and myself, haha.So, that's my first impression. I'm very satisfied until now, and I'm still learning all the possibilities. For now the universe of X Rebirth is teaching me about all the ways I can play.• "Familiar" Impression [next]

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Do not buy this... abomination. It will be months, maybe even years before all of the glitches, bugs, Artificial Intelligence, framerate, and interface issues get resolved, if ever. Bugs can be patched, AI can be fixed, but even then, the game still might not be salvagable. It is the core design choices built into the game itself that is the real problem.1) The entire UI needs to be completely scrapped and redone from the ground up. It is just that bad.2) The System:Sector:Zone map scheme is absurdly frustrating, to say the least.3) Nearly all of the gameplay elements Egosoft has spent years introducing, refining, and polishing in the X series have been scrapped. No more SETA to speed up tedious portions, no more jumpdrive in the ship you actually pilot, no more autopilot, no more sector/universal traders, no more realtime monitoring of commodity prices using a satellite network, no more customizable keybinding, no more hotkeys to cycle through targets (you literally have to click on a ship w/ your cursor to highlight them and get aim-assist).As many others have said before me, this simply isn't an 'X' game. They should have called it 'Y'. As in Y the hell would anyone play this?It pains me to write this. I know Egosoft is comprised a a dedicated bunch who have a long history of commitment to thier customers. Few companies come to mind that are as noble as Egosoft when it comes to taking thier fanbase seriously. I want to extend them every benefit of the doubt, but good intentions will only go so far. This game, right now, as of November 25, 2013, is complete garbage. Complete garbage produced over a 7 year period a team with years of experience designing space-sims who really really REALLY should have known better.Here's to hoping the modding community can fix what Egosoft has broken. My heart.

Posted: November 26, 2013
												Don't play it..just don't. The video trailers are completely misleading, as were all the hypes and promises made by EgoSoft. The voice acting is terrible, sounding like someone reading (for the first time) off a script with little to no emotion. The NPCs are all static and don't move anywhere around the cut-and-paste station interiors. No matter what the station looks like on the outside, it'll probably look pretty much the same on the inside.Combat is clunky- the first bit of combat where you fight a couple of drones, your ship maneuvers like a stoned whale, so you can barely hit them, and from what I've seen from others, this doesn't particularly improve.While the universe, artistically, is gorgeous...the rest, not so much.If you want to travel from point A to point B, you'll have to fly manually the whole way, often using the weird space-highway system. Having to circle a station for 5-10 minutes to find where you're supposed to dock adds to the frustation.As does suddenly losing a chance at being liked by an NPC due to some sort of (completely unexplained) conversation minigame coming up and disappearing before you know what's happening.Your supposed crew members looking after your ships have all the intelligence of a sub-average brick. They have to be told exactly what to do (and sometimes still won't do it) through a maze of menus and submenus. Your co-pilot is worse- she throws random lines out here and there which make no sense whatsoever, her voice acting is terrible and cliched, and she provides no extra purpose to the game beyond being an annoyance.OVERALL:While the space-graphics are pretty, and there's a lot to potentially do....the game is fundamentally fubared, with some parts completely ambiguous, others blatantly and utterly broken, and the majority of it frustrating.Conclusion:Don't buy it, like I did. I'm really wanting to ask for a refund.

content:
Posted: August 29, 2014
												So, I'm a fan of space sims.  I love X3, X3 Terran Conflict and X3 Albion Prelude.  The sheer scale of the open world in the old games was incredible, play as a mercenary, military officer, pirate, trader or entrepenuer.  The choice was yours.  So, when I heard that X Rebirth was in the works, I was over the moon.  I was right up there excited about what was promised to be the most immersive X game yet.  The reality is quite different.  If you want the short version, skip to summary.I'll start with the positives: The game is, astetically beautiful.  Ripe with amazing models, seemless transitions between sectors and the freelancer highway system, the effects, reflections and graphical detail are incredible.  Adding further to the immersion is the ability to walk around your ship and talk to crew.It also had a tutorial that put a nice ease on the learning curve.Now the negatives: Now I mentioned walking around your ship.  Yes, this is cool.  Unfortunately, the only ship the player can control is the Pride of Albion.  While the ship is able to recieve upgrades, the real beauty of the X3 games (for me) was the ability to fly nearly any ship.  You could fly a fighter, a bomber, a cargoship, a transport, a megafreighter, even battleships and fighter carriers.  As far as I'm aware, you can't even use mods to change your player ship (or if you can, nobody has bothered to create one).  The hidden beauty of the X3 games was their moddability.  Ship models are availiable for download (for free) on egosoft's forums for the older games.  For me, I view this as a real missed oportunity.  They were able to extend the projectile distances in the new engine by quite a ways.  This meant that capital class vessels really could initiate gun based artillery duels.  The tragic truth is that without the ability to change ships, you can witness these battles, but you can't directly control them.Summary: At the end of the day, I feel that Egosoft missed the mark.  Instead of polishing gameplay and their gem, customization, Egosoft took the root that so many gamers are frustrated with: shiny coat of paint on a mediocre game.  As Minecraft and Sword of the Stars II have shown, the game itself is what makes a game successful.  Gameplay is more important than the shiny ships and pretty explosions.  You can have a great game with 8 bit graphics and it will still sell.  But you can't have a  dodgy game in 1080p and expect many good reviews.Addendum: I am looking at this game as a fan of previous X games.  I think as far as sapce shooters go, it's alright, but it is a bit of a departure from the previous games.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												A terrible, terrible game, and a massive disappointment. X games are always rough on release, filled with bugs and all kinds of problems. But at the core, they offer a deep and rewarding space sim sandbox experience. The clunky UI and sheer scope of the game overwhelms most first time players. But when you finally overcome all obstacles, you're in for a real treat which might consume most of your social life. With all that in mind, i pre-ordered this game. It was supposed to be a PC exclusive, hardcore space sim. It was made by seasoned developers with years of experience under their belts. And man, look at those graphics! What could go wrong here? Pretty much everything.X Rebirth is pretty. The space cities look amazig, they're richly detailed, there's plenty of space ship traffic around them, and the game looks really nice at first glance. The backdrops are simply stunning. Every sector has its own unique look and feel. It's by far the best looking space game to date. And that's the end of the positives.The interface has been overhauled, supposedly, to be more accessible. In reality, we get something both newcomers and old time veterans will have hard time getting used to. The UI is once again unintuitive and badly thought out. Half of the stuff you could do in previous X games has been thrown out of the window. There's no radar. The world map is unreadable. You can't give out basic orders to ships under your command. You can't tell if they're moving or not. You can't see their destination, speed etc... But if that's not enough, you can't even switch between your targets with the keyboard! In a god damn space sim! You can't rebind most of the keys either. And every time you want to check something on your ship's computer (the main UI window), you're forced to watch an annoying animation.The game is filled with pointless minigames. There's a minigame for pretty much everything you do. From flying through space highways or walking through space stations (in search for random containers filled with loot and free credits), to gathering collectible points for shop discounts or scanning your nearest vicinity for random junk floating around in space. They're pointless, tedious and repetitive. And they definitely don't belong in a space sim.You can now walk freely inside the space stations. A nice idea - in theory, but in this case it's just another chore this game didn't need. There are 3 different space station layouts. Do i need to say they get old pretty fast? And they're filled with butt-ugly, lifeless NPCs, which are nothing more than a visual representation of the trading/ship managment UI. The voice acting is as bad as you'd expect from Egosoft, except, it's actually even worse. Prepare to listen to your main protagonist repeat the same lines over and over again, making the infamous Bethesda "arrow in the knee" or "i saw a mudcrab the other day" lines look fresh and original.The game world is small. That's the cost you have to pay for those pretty graphics. And the persistent, reactive world we were promissed was a lie. Rebirth's world is filled with constant traffic. There are hundreds of ships, large and small, moving through space. But most of them are there just for show. For example, hardly anything leaves of enters the highways. So, in reality, the world is mostly filled with dummy props and cool looking graphical effects.Oh, and there are bugs. Serious, gamebreaking bugs that make you lose hours of gameplay. The AI behaves in ridiculous ways... when it's not completely idle. That's especially annoying if it happens to one of your ships.The game is bad, and don't hope it will ever improve. It's broken at its very core. No ammount of patches and mods will undo 7 years of bad design and pointless features. Seriously, if you're a fan, stick to X3 and its expansions, if not, get X3: TC or AP. Don't waste your money on this steaming pile of fertilizer like i did. I bought it so you don't have to.

Posted: January 4, 2016
												This is the crappiest game I've have ever played!  Why?  Of the 7.1 hours I played, 6.5 of that was just figuring out keyboard commands with the lack of documentation provided by the game.  I finally gave up.  I’ve figured out command lines for Cisco network switchs' advanced configurations faster than I have learned how to engage basic functions in this poor excuse for a video game.Oh, I don't mind a complex command layout—Freespace 1-2 had some of the most complex commands in a video game and they were epic games—but these developers failed to document the commands.  That is a serious problem: complex command structures combined with little to no documentation or tutorial.  Definitely an Underpants Gnome’s recipe for profit.For example: early mission – acquire captain for your freighter.  Ok, no prob.  Get to said station, something Labs something.  It’s big.  Looking for a docking port.  Not showing one.  Looking at map, not showing a docking port.  Followed the beacon, takes you to a generic point on station.  Knock on the station “door” with the front of my ship – no answer.  Guess nobody’s home.  OK, consult in game control settings at this point (Esc > settings > control).  In the last X games, it’s comms, request permission for docking.  Tried that first, mind you, yet there is no comms with the station at all (a space station that does not talk to anybody, intereseting).  Going through settings > controls, nothing about acquiring/hiring personnel from a station that will not answer comms.  Out of desperation, just start hitting all other buttons to see if something works.  ‘I’ was the one—because, you know, the info menu is the logical place to put hire commands—and I was able to hire a caption after further difficulties with the info menu.  At no point in this little adventure did the game give you instructions.  All this took only 2 hours.Moving on.  Next objective: deliver said captain to freighter.  Get to freighter.  Again, no comms.  Ah, but I learned the magic ‘I’ command now.  Nope, nothing.  Ok, tried generic ‘F’.  Again, nothing.  It did let me ‘Auto-follow’ the freighter though, so decided to see how that worked for later because following ships is important in most escort missions.  Oh, bad bad mistake.  When you auto-follow, it takes away all your steering functions and speed controls.  And you know what happens when you follow a ship that is not going anywhere?  You sit there with no controls, no ability to accelerate, no comms, no ‘I’ of ‘F’ menus.  Nothing.  You sit there.  And you stare.  And you contemplate your meaningless existence playing this meaningless game.  And because you are in space, no one will ever hear you scream.  At this point, I’m struggling to keep calm.  Again, checked the setting > controls for help.  Surely they list the key command to disengage the auto-follow.  Surely.  Nope, FU player!  There is only two times in my life that I ever got so mad at a game that I literally snapped a keybroad in half and threw its parts across the room.  One, when my Lustitanni infantry wouldn’t take orders to adjust its position for a Roman flank attack in an epic 3-hour long battle I had in Rome: Europa Barbarorum (there is no saving in a battle sequence), and here when there was literally no way to disengage an auto-follow on a ship that was not going anywhere.  The first was a delight born out of a wonderful challenge in a great game, but this time was out of a sincere desire to hunt down developers to exterminate with extreme prejudice.After finding another keyboard and pulling the embedded half of the old one out of the sheet rock of my wall, I decided to reassess and continue.  Surely, I missed something.  Surely, no one would design a game so crappy that they would not document their user commands.  Loaded from another point and tried again.  Get to freighter, copilot says something about docking—well, no♥♥♥♥♥♥Sherlock.  Finally see the docking section of the freighter were ‘F’ works (not comms mind you, because that would make too much sense—see, I’m getting the hang of how these jerks think}.  Select dock, docking cut scene, now standing in my cargo hold.  The screen flashes a brief hint to tell your new captain to take command of the freighter by “[MAINMENU] 7-1”…  WTF does that mean?  I hit the ‘7’ key.  Nothing.  I try all commands I learned up til this point.  Nothing.  OK, I logically conclude that I have to find this magical [MAINMENU] that the hint speaks of.  Go to settings > controls.  Nowhere does it reference a main menu.  Oh, I have info on dialogue menus, I have flight and platform menus.  It will tell me how to walk and talk, how to take a♥♥♥♥♥♥in the station corner, but nothing about a [MAINMENU] or any other main menu at all.  Not a single reference.  By this time, I had wasted 7.1 hours of my life on this trash.  The game is just poorly designed.  I sincerely believe I spent more time writing this review of my experience than these crackhead excuses for developers spent in writing a reference guide for their ♥♥♥♥♥♥ game.  So much potential, such waste.  And I do have the TO bundle with all current content until this point (Jan, 2016), because I know some people were like “it got better after TO DLC released.”  Well, if it was crappier than it is now, then may the video game gods have no mercy on the souls of Egosoft developers.  If I ran a software development company, I would thoroughly watch the credits to write down all the names of every professional who worked on this game and blacklist them from ever being hired in my company.  Yes, this game is seriously that bad.

content:
Posted: June 3, 2015
												X Rebirth is the marriage of an economic simulator with an arcade flight sim. The basic gameplay centers around completing various missions for pay and reputation with different factions. Inbetween these, you manage your other assets, including myriad capital ships, freighters, mining vessels, and space stations.Combat sends you against marauding fighter bands and massive carriers, hostile space stations and shoals of drones. Shield energy powers your boosters, meaning the player must choose when to fight and when to run, and guessing wrong with leave them naked and stranded under fire. Enemy fighters dogfight with the player and each other. Huge capital ships can wreak havoc, but their engines, turrets, and shield projectors are vulnerable to damage. The weak AI is an issue, and larger targets can seem rather bullet-spongey for a player with few resources. Still, disabling and capturing that troublesome destroyer near your new factory is very satisfying.On the economic side of things, the Great Material Continuum flows like a river from station to staion in the form mass traffic, cargo vessels, and large frieghters. And it is constantly under attack from pirates and other hostile forces. This means there are plenty of opportunities for would-be tycoons. Materials must be mined. Food must be grown. Parts must be manufactured. Freight must be transported. Ships but be built and supplied. Stations must be constructed and defended. And everything needs staffing. It's a lot of fun to plan out your installation and manage its construction and operation. Oddly moreso when you've screwed up something and have to rework everything on the fly.While I recommend the X Rebirth, it's certainly not for everyone. It's a trainset of a game, crossing into simulation territory just enough to be intellectually stimulating, while still providing the visceral thrill of arcade space combat. It's a casual-friendly game that lets you dip your toes into the deep end of the pool.Happily Youtube has come to the rescue of the scrutinous. Mylo-s did a fairly thorough playthrough of the gameplay mechanics. While there are some plot spoilers, the plot itself is just an overgrown gameplay tutorial.

Posted: January 4, 2015
												I'm an older gamer who's been playing video since I was twelve (Pong and Asteroids, anyone?)I rarely write reviews. Some games are great and I enjoy them immensely. Others disappoint and I end up regretting the time and money I spent on them. But I rarely feel inclined to wade into the fray. For X Rebirth, I've decided to make an exception.I've been addicted to space games forever. X-Wing vs. Tie Fighter. Homeworld, Sins of a Solar Empire, Eve Online, Galactic Civilizations, Distant Worlds. Evochron. The X Series. I've played them all at one time or another.X Rebirth is a game I've had my eye long before it was released.  Well, the release didn't go well (understatement) and the plethora of bugs and complaints kept me on the sidelines for almost a year. Well, this holiday season, I decided that  with the release of 3.0 and a sizable discount, I'd bite the bullet.  I always felt the screenshots looked great, but I really wasn't expecting much, especially in light of its notorious history.Well, color me surprised, because I'm loving this game!  The flight mechanics (and graphics) are awesome and after a couple of dozen hours, I haven't run into a bug yet. It's got a fairly steep learning curve  (with Trading, Building, Crafting and such), but with a game of this complexity, that's to be expected.What I didn't really expect was for Egosoft to continue suporting this game and turning a steaming pile of digital garbage into one of the most enjoyable gaming experiences I've had all year. So, Egosoft, shame on you for releasing a broken game. But Thank You, sincerely, for sticking with it and turning it into an encredibly enoyable Space Sim.If you like casually flying around a HUGE open world (universe?) and picking and choosing the role you want to play within it, then I strongly recommend giving this game a chance. Like me, you may just end up loving it.

												After the 3.1 update, this game finaly is what it should be since the release. Egosoft fixed a lot of bugs and its finaly good enougth to play and you wont have any more problems, I promise !I pre-ordered the collectors edition, on release date I skipped school just to play it from the first moment. After the installation I sat down with my can of redbull and chips, I was hyped to Albion and back, I was so ♥♥♥♥ing hyped, I was the hypetrain itself. BUT after the first 2 hours of gameplay I just sat infront of my PC, tears in my eyes, clinching my teath. My body was shakeing, I was angry, so angry. You had failed me Egosoft, I spend hours of my life playing your games, I played X: Reunion around 800 hours and X: Albion prelude around 500. I was so disapointed, you failed me, YOU *UCKIN FAILED ME !I didnt touch the game, or just rarely when they released new updates...but after some time it came to my mind that you, dear Egosoft, builded a new game from scratch. You left the old X behind, you made something truely new, something unique, something fantastic... after this reaisation I wasnt mad anymore... you build a new game from scratch, with a new engine, with a new AI and with new graphics/ships/stations, it took a lot of work, a lot of willpower and a lot of blood to create the basics...but you did it. It wasnt finished, but it does not have to be. You Egosoft, you care about your games, and this is what came back in my mind. The first X3: Reunion build was buggy as hell, the skripts didnt work the halft time and ships constantly crashing in my stations and jumpgates...but you fixed a lot in the first months/years...AND you did the same with X: Rebirth...after a year its finaly that what it should be, a masterpiece...and I know there is much more to come, because Egosoft, you CARE about your games and I just can tell every player/owner, buy/play this game, it is worth it. Its playable, dont listen to the people who are trying to badmouth it. X:Rebirth is complex, its difficult to programm and you should give it a try. Its good money and you spend, I know but its worth every penny, because Egosoft gives you free DLCs and Patches, Fixes and content for the next years. Now to the game: Gameplay: Massive changes to trade/build/fight/explore-content, you only own a single ship now, the Albions Pride/Skunk. Many people see this as a downside but I like it. You can change it to your likeing (new engines, cockpit, weapons, etc.).Also tradeing and building got more time consuming and rewarding, because you realy feel like you have archived something. Missions realy pay out now, not the crappy 20k for fighting fregatts or whole fleets, now you can easily earn millions with one misson (it will be a difficult one, but fun) so yes...overall a little bit more difficult.AI: Meh, there's still room for improvement, but thats normal. You have nice fights but you mostly will get beaten because of the mass of the enemys fleet. Soundtrack:A.W.E.S.O.M. 'nougth said !Graphics: WAY better than "X3: XXXXXX"s Graphics. Nice improvements - still its hardwareconsuming, so watch out. Maybe Egosoft will reduce it in some more patches.Fazit: solid 8.5/10 from the current phase, maybe a 9 for the free DLC, thx for that :D

content:
Posted: November 20, 2013
												I have finished the plot and have 65 game hours on the clock. I sit looking at the screen thinking “now what?” Put the bugs and performance issues to one side for now (I am reasonably confident they will be dealt with), this game appears to have nothing in store but tedium now the plot guidance has disappeared.I need to make money in order to progress. The prospect of either long range scanning, or constantly flying around huge stations to try and get missions or establish what is for sale/wanted fills me with despair. Especially as I have yet been able to establish how I get my freighters to refuel. Is the only way to do this be by ordering them to buy something then telling them to buy fuel first when they tell me they have no fuel? (that has yet to work BTW). I have the trading software and even though I have traversed from the end of the plot to Far Out, I bring up the trading menu and there seems to be little that I can buy, what little that is available I cannot sell as I am an enemy to most of the stations that require the wares (PMC). What am I progressing to? Is my purpose solely to get the economy going? Can you order a cap ship to attack something?That station I built, due to bugs and not being able to find freighters that held the required materials for building the various sections, was mostly completed by hacking the save. It has yet to produce a single item for sale. Modular station design seems to be a good idea, only being able to select and build one module at a time seems bizarre. Especially when I cannot seem to be able to contact the architect remotely (I can’t even comm the captain and ask them to go and get the architect). Backwards and forwards again and again, why would I do that for more than the required station? Please tell me that it is different for a construction ship that isn’t part of the plot.I have mixed feelings regarding the use of shield energy to boost speed, if I knew how many enemy ships were close, trying to kill me and what type of ship they were it would be a good idea (I can make a judgement call and run if need be).  But as I can only see red triangles at the edge of the screen I do not have enough information to know when to run.“Shut up Betty” was funny the first time. The highway mini game was was fun the first few times. Hacking while your co-pilot seems happy to let the ship get blown to pieces is ridiculous. Hacking in general is ridiculous once you throw the mini game into the equation along with some hacking points being many km’s apart. I am not going to comment on the small talk mini game. A mod has put paid to “shut up Betty”, I refuse to play the highway mini game anymore and I had no choice with hacking.Clusters are too small, the distance between them is too large and I am loathe to jump out of a highway on the off chance that there may be something interesting. Writing this wall of text has allowed me to determine what is wrong, in my mind, with the game. All of the fun, mystery and potential sense of achievement has been removed. I don’t want to micro manage on a face to face basis. The saddest part is that now I have finished the plot I don’t know if I want to fire the game up again.Maybe the complete lack of any useful game information (how to, what is, why does etc.) is keeping me from the best gaming experience of my life. I may never find out.

Nope not for me anyway.What is the "elevator pitch" for people to upgrade to this game? How is it an upgrade. I can see what it removes from X3 Albion Prelude, and sometimes removing things is a good design choice (though I don't think many nerfs in this game are good) but what Rebirth actually add?At the moment it's playing OK for me. Just.Being stuck in one ship is a terrible design choice, one I think the developers will regret in the long term.Simplfying the trade. Those of use who loved the supply chain logistics of previous X games will be very upset this is almost completely nerfed here. One station does it all.Simpler? Yes More enjoyable? Nope not for me anyway.Combat has been dumbed down. Choices removed.Things like the stock exchange that was present in AP has gone, the none campaign missions also seem gone.The graphics while ok are not better than AP either (this is a direct X 9.0c game after all, so is running the same technology as the original X3 more or less)I'm not saying this is a bad game, just can't see the point of it existing who did Egosoft make it for? How is it more advanced or better than the last X3 update? I've only put 8 and a half hours in so far, but I might as well write this now, as I can't see me playing any more. It just seems to lack the depth and rewarding complexity of the last games. I'm looking for "new" or "innovative" and can find nothing... at all. Am I missing something?In short even when fixed, I'm not sure why I would play this in preference to Albion Prelude which is a larger, more mature, deeper and more rewarding game that looks the same (if not better) plays more smoothly...If anyone could answer that question I'd love to hear from them .WHY NOT TO BUY THIS GAME!1. Being stuck in one ship, Yep only one Ship not 86+ like the old X games2. Graphics are dated, looks worse the X3:R from 20053. There is no immersion, You got it no immersion AT ALL4. Voice acting is utterly terrible, Get Ready for B Grade voice acting as thats all you hear5. Supply chain logistics of previous X games, GONE 100% GONE!6. Comanding your  Ships, Again you must go though your NPC's to do anything and that Takes Forever and ever and does not help that you have no idea what your doing at all.10. content:
Posted: February 23, 2014
												I've Where to start.  Firslty, it is very clear that this game was not finished at release.  I've been waiting until around a few days ago to give it a try.  Egosoft has still not come through with the patches they promised.  The trading is completly bugged and if one thing is done wrong it flat out does not work.  The navigation system is not only confusing and buggy but is near impossible to find the information you need/want to know.  Combat can be fun at times.  It feels a little slow to pace and from time to time you simply explode for no reason.  The game has a good look to it but the cockpit feels completly worthless and has almost no value as far as mechanic.  And lastly, not only do you have to leave the cockpit to talk to your crew but the ship only has one room on it.  Somehow with one room (that has nothing functional in it) can fit you, your co-pilot, an engineer, eight marines, and a marine captain on it.  It has a few very cool festures like how to scan for long range.  the station landing feels very dry and unpolished as well as the fact that your ship can be attacked while you are docked and can plainly see it on the landing pad.  The game feels like it was the test system the quickly slapped some polish on and said "That's good enough, right?"  All in all, I wouldn't recomend this game to anyone until Egosoft fixes most, if not all of the problems with it.  Personally, I feel that I have been scammed by Egosoft and they should be ashamed of themselves for even releasing this game.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												As a longtime player of the X series, this game bears no resemblance to those fantastic engrossing predecessors.  Gone are the  deep levels of control over your great financial empire and gone are the deep levels of control of your own ship!Being limited to a single ship isn't worth the tiny benefit of walking around a 3-room vessel in which you can only interact in one room.Being able to land and get out of your ship isn't worth the pain of looking at the zombie-esque tortured faces of your business contacts on the space stations, and t isn't worth listening to their awful dialog.The Minigames of : Spacelane Travel, Dialogue/Sweet-talking, Galaxy spacelane travel & Spacestation scanning for trade discounts are all painful.There is no fleet management system and that's good because i'm not sure what I'd do with a fleet in this poorly designed game.Trade is cumbersome, communications is cumbersome, navigation is cumbersome, flight over distance without autopilot is cumbersome.The map system in this game is the worst map system I have ever seen in any game.  Really.  I believe it was designed by a person who does not know how to read actual maps.  The ability to manipulate the map is gone, you can't zoom out or in, you can't scroll anywhere and there is no facility to allow orientation to any map objects.I have always thought of the X games as a PC game.  I don't know their console history, and perhaps there is some, but this game with it's very limited key choices and lack of commands as well as it's obvious wheel-oriented menu options was obviously intended to be controlled by a game controller.  I do not and never will have a game controller attached to my PC.I get the feeling that this was never designed by the people who made the X games.  The departures are so stark, the changes are so dramatic and the design elements are so cumbersome and yet so limited that I think this game is something else entirely.  I feel like they just put the X game on a piece of trash so they could get my $60.This game is very beautiful in space.  There I wrote something nice.Don't buy this game.

content:
Posted: February 16, 2014
												24 patches and still an unpolished turd.I've been one of the people that preordered the game, fully expecting bugs to happen, same as with all the previous X series games. I've been with the series since X-BtF. I've made it through the glitchy first versions of X2 and X3:Reunion alike. I had fun.Rebirth is different. The engine itself shows potential, but everything tacked onto it is a mess. Even completely disregarding the bugs in the economy and storyline, the game is still bad. The UI design is horrid and needs a complete overhaul. Most of the features that made the previous games great are missing entirely or dumbed down to the point of uselessness. Many of the new features that were tacked on are badly thought out or lackluster.Yisha is the most obnoxious sidekick I ever encountered in games period. The fact that on the first days after release mods were popping up to shut her the hell up speaks volumes. Same for Ren's terribly repetitive lines every time you talk to an NPC. The entire trading/station scanning concept is a horrendous cluster♥♥♥♥. The hacking/smalltalk minigame is ridiculous.Despite promises to the contrary, modders still don't have all the tools they need to polish this turd. The playership is hardcoded to the Skunk. The UI is all in compiled lua that is more or less impossible to modify without the sources, which the Modders still don't have. The engine itself shows great potential, but Egosoft still isn't really letting the community at it.All that that leaves one with is a semi-decent space shooter. And there are other games that do this a lot better, for a much lower pricetag.Scripting support aaside, it has all the marks of a rushed and terribly botched console port, despite being developed exclusively for the PC. Patches are slowly fixing this: We now get targeting hotkeys for the keyboard, for one. Ha.There are two rays of light, though: While most of the modding community already gave up on this game, some are still working away at it, and many of the smaller annoyances have been fixed thanks to the community. Egosoft has a stellar record when it comes to supporting their games even years after release, even adding new content long after releasing a patch that completely removed DRM, both for TC and AP.I'd say with another year or so and a solid UI revamp, this game could truly shine. Let's just hope Egosoft doesn't go bankrupt by then, and that they don't wait with opening up their Lua sources for too long.For now, though: Very definitely not recommended. Grab it at the next WInter Sale.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2013
												This game is such a travesty to the X franchise i had to write my first review (probably only).If you are new to the X franchise you may actually find the game interesting for awhile before you find out just how shallow it really is. After the campaign there is NOTHING to do. And the campaign itselt is a bugridden nightmare of how not to create an interesting plot.Lets go through its shortcomings:1. The trade part of the game is, show stopping bugs aside, shallow. You, the player, are the only one who uses money for an example. Alot of the items being produced are for building ships. Which the shipyards will do regardless of if the NPC or the player orders any. It will simply churn ships out. If there was no need for it, the AI will take the ship out of sight and delete it from the game (literally). So there is no real "supply and demand" in function. If anything, its a plan economy which the soviet union demonstrated never worked. Yet they implement just that in X Rebirth - and oddly enough it doesnt work. How about that! Rating: 1/102. Fight... Well if you like fancy graphics and dont really care that your ship is superior in every way and can just "boost" (afterburn) its way out of any fight that starts to become challenging this game may be for you. Unless you play with a joystick - because they made an xbox controller the featured item for this game. (Yes this was supposed to have been an xbox release 3-4 years ago or so but obviously such a poor game that it was never allowed by MS to be released). You have no way of "tab targetting" as they apparantly think chasing icons on the edge of your field of vision is awesome - that apparantly is set to 60 degrees as well. If you are in a system with a red sun its almost impossible to keep track of said icons. You get the idea. And dont get me started on the whole drone thing. Terrible idea with a terrible implementation. Your so called "co-pilot" which was apparantly going to be piloting your ship while youre busy controlling a drone - doesnt. So you get your♥♥♥♥♥blown off. Brilliant. Rating: 2/103. Building stations was one of the interesting things in the past, as you could set up your own trade empire and compete over sectors if thats what you wanted. They have actually thought out of the box in a nice way this time, allowing you to make huge complexes. Great idea. But then they couldnt have you build your stations just anywhere. No there will be 2 maybe 3 slots where you can place it. So much for freedom. There is also the part about "why" you would want to build anything as you are the only one who needs money to fund stuff - and making money is extremely (too) easy. Rating: 3/104. Thinking about this game makes my heart hurt. I preordered this game because the X series had been a great experience for me in the past. It no longer is. The campaign is long and unrewarding. The economy is fake so there is no incentive to try and corner any part of the market or try to take a competing (enemy) corporation out. They have no money, they need no money, so they can never be "beaten". So what is there left to do? Nothing. Space combat boring and uninspiring. After a few boarding/captures of capital ships that gets boring too. The placefiller/timesink minigames makes you want to scream. About 1/3 of your time will be WASTED in the highways, in the past you could zoom past boring parts of the game with SETA which allowed you to increase time by factors up to 10 so you didnt have to sit and watch paint dry, sorry i mean wait patiently for your ship to arrive at the next destination so you can jump out of the highways. Rating: 2/10Other parts of the game i will cover here:Graphics: I will not lie, the new engine makes space look truly awesome. Stations, NPCs and the skunk itself is a whole other story. And you cant look around the cockpit nor look at your ship from the outside. So minus a few points there. It has a few issues (no doubt because it was programmed for the xbox360) where really high end machines run worse than medium/low end machine. But pretty thats for sure. put 1-2 points on when it gets bugfixed. Rating: 6/10Music: Great as always, that is one of the parts of the game i always enjoyed. The beautiful score. Sound effects and the voice acting? Not so much, but i feel its adequate for this game. Rating: 7/10Gameplay: It would probably be easier to say whats actually working for this game which is... nothing. Literally. I have sunk about 16 hours into this game and i havent felt like starting it up again for weeks. And i used to love the X series and have sunk hundreds of hours into them. content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												I am 11 hours into the game, an unfortunately there are many glaring flaws in this game. I believe most of the technical issues will eventually be resolved, but there are some serious design issues which really drag this game down.I have long been a fan of the X series and I have been looking forward to this game for months, so my experience might be colored somewhat by my disappointment. I have been plagued with poor performance, constant game crashes which sometimes require a reboot to get out of, and numerous glitches in the trading system and missions that make advancement impossible.Again, the technical issues will be resolved via patching. What may not be resolved are the design choices that depart from previous X games. To list:1. You can no longer hop from ship to ship. You can own multiple ships and you can issue them limited orders, but your starting ship will be your ending ship and it will be the only one you pilot.2. The trading network has been neutered. You can only issue trade commands for your freighters to sell or purchase goods in their system only. You can't set up the elaborate chains that were possible in X:TC.3. Voice acting: You are chained to another character that has some of the worst voice acting I've heard since Final Fantasy X.4. Menus, sub menus, sub-sub-menus: You can't just buy a gun or missile while floating in space. You need to dock your ship, walk to the individual merchant, open a conversation, request to see their goods, request to see their missiles, then request to buy them, then tell them how many you want. Seriously, restocking missiles is a 5-minute ordeal after every fight.I think I see where they wanted to go with this game. They wanted to make it more appealing to the masses that were previously turned off by the massive learning curve the series holds. Unfortunately, instead of streamlining the game mechanics they just hid them behind a poorly-designed and time-consuming interface which is somehow more painful to deal with than the spreadsheets of the older games.I want to like this game so much, but there are just too many jagged edges to get much actual enjoyment.

												So far this game has gone full retard.  Visually it's very cool but don't be fooled it's full of game breaking glitches.  First of all if you do buy this game be sure to save often as it will randomly have game breaking errors.  In the first 5 hours it happened to me 3 times, the first time I lost over an hour of gameplay.  Following the campaign The mining company is now hostile with me and open fire everytime they are near my ship.  Neutral space stations everywhere will do absolutely nothing when these ships fire on mine but if I return fire the immidiately respond against me.  So what is the character the only person subject to the law in the entire universe?  In addition to that I'm on a mission where I apparently have to use a Trojan ROV except I don't have one and i've been to 4 different drone dealers none of which sell them.  I've looked at the mission screen multiple times and it gives me no information at all.  So now I'm going to youtube to look for answers as to what the **** I'm supposed to do on this mission to advance the plot.  Furthermore I was in another area where I had to boost past some enemy ships to get through a gate, but the characters were talking.  I boosted through before they were finished and the game made me go back through the gate only to come back again before it would update the navigation point lmfao.  One last thing.  When you start the story mode you get a cargo ship with weapons and shields that the story has you purchase crew members for and even place in your squad so it follows you around.  There is even a mission where you have to use your cargo vessel to ship something for you.  The point I'm at now that ship has just vanished!  I know exactly where it was and how much health it had.  I also had a captain, an engineer, and a security officer on it all of which cost money.  It was never in a battle it has just vanished.  It's not in my property owned screen anymore it's just gone for no reason.If you want a big headache then this is the game for you.  Bugs and glitches as well as improperly done triggers have repeatedly pulled me out of the immersion and made me very much aware that I'm playing a video game.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												I wanted to like this game very badly. That said, it's a terrible game. Egosoft screwed up the launch horribly, and while it's commendable that they've fixed a lot of the game-breaking bugs in the last two months, the game is still a terrible game. It's fundamentally unfun. Virtually every game mechanic can be summed up as "tedious" at best.Escort missions take 20 minutes of sitting around waiting for something to happen, followed by 5 seconds of combat, followed by 10 more minutes of waiting for the ship being escorted to dock. Travel between sectors takes forever, even when piggybacking on a jump drive capable ship. Of course, if you do piggyback on something, it's guaranteed to die when it inevitably passes through an impossible-to-avoid PMC controlled zone. If instead you just send it through alone, no problem, emerges unscathed, through the miracle of out-of-sector combat!Trading takes forever, and station-building relies on trading at its core, so that's twice as tedious. Half the materials you need will be obtainable mostly through hijacking freighters. Guess what? Hijacking anything is also tedious with yet another timesink there. And what is the reward for all these timesinks? Cool things to upgrade your ship with? Nope. Awesome new ships you can buy? Haha, no. Maybe some new capability for your stations or something? Get real. Usually it's just "Yay, I got to advance the plot to where it showcases the next horrible game mechanic!" Best part: The ending. I won't spoil it for you. But basically, all of a sudden, the plot just... ends. If the game was amazing, that could maybe have been forgiven as the expansion pack hook, leaving you wanting more. But in this game, it was more a sigh of relief. This stupid thing is finally over.
