content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
												I wanted this game to be the next step of the X series. It has been the case that with every new one, it offered the same as the last one, but with better and more features. So it was from the first one, all the way to X:AP. From what we were told it would be, we expected the end of "tubing" our stations to make it a complex, the end of gateways were out ship were colliding with others comming out, and of course better graphics.Instead we received a game that only has the same races and a few mentions to the previous universe. Everything else is working differently, making this not the next X game, but anothing game set in space. Graphics in space are beautiful, but everything else is awkward, ugly, repetitive and annoying. Trade mechanics started broken, but even if they are fixed take an age to complete, and without advanced autopilot commands, are hard to provide enjoyment.A graphics user interface built around the needs of the least common denominator (which in this game is the Xbox controller) means that the keyboard and joystick are severely limited by design and it took only forum remarks to get the developers to promise to add a few keyboard commands, while going off and apologizing that those will not be included in the Xbox controller. While the gamepad incorporation should be an option for those that want to use one, it should always be handled as the most important commands and controlls peripheral and not a way to work everything in the game, as that leads (as it had) to a very simple interface for a very complex game. This means that previous complex menus in X games are now gone and to do anything you have to go over much more steps than before! Yes, the previous menus seemed complex, but that was only because the game itself was complex. The menus were very well designed to offer control and everyone that ever loved the game had a very good understanding of how the menus worked, because they loved all the complexity the game had to offer. Having a steep learning curve was never an issue for his game, it had to have it, because it had so much to offer once you were on the other side.New additions to the game to deal with previous problem areas are equally not well thought out. The simplest one should have been the traveling between sectors. The problem in the past was that every one had to go through a gate to go to the next sector, and that introduced problems like big ships entering through that gate would intrfeer with the small ships comming out (or the reverse) causing AI pathfinding problems and crashes between ships. The solution was a highway system, that is fast, one way, and involved a mini game based on being caught in the wake of another to speed up in the lane. Aside from this being irrelevant, one could just not use it, but as there is no autopilot to tell it to take you to that system or that station, you hace to fly manually and wait while you get there and make notice to get out in the right area or the trip will just continue until the end of the lane.First of all, why no autopilot? There always was an autopilot, X:R doesn't have one.Secondly, there is one element that makes sence, one way travel, but that would be all the solution needed for the problem. Introducing one way gates would solve the single problem that existed with the gate system.Thirdly, where before we entered and exited the gates in one or two seconds, we now have to wait to fly between sectors and unless you want to play the minigame, the travelling can become long and extremely boring.This means that lanes offer the solution to the previous games, while introducing new problems we never had before. Good design ths is not.There are further design choices like this made throughout the game. Big stations are great and beautiful, but to read them all you have to fly extremely close to all modules of a station and on the correct side of the module as that is the only one offering the magical  ( i ) icon, which I assume would point to the only antenna on the module that allows communication to your ship's scanners so that you can get the information. So gone are the days of scanning a station from 25km away (or longer if one had triplex scanners) and learning all there was to know, now we are reduced to a few meters of scannign range for one module that has to be facing us correctly. There is no reason to do something like this in any space game I have ever played - or hope to play.Maps in the game are big unwieldy things, as if they were designed to be seen by someone still playing of a PAL monitor. In this day wher an HDReady resolution is considered low for a PC monitor, the maps are so big that waste screen realestate and become nonfunctional. Bind this together with a control system that is again not the right one, and figuring out the maps becomes a hussle.The same low density that exists for the game maps continues to your assets listings, quickly filling up with only a few of them when the X games were typical of the player having many hundreds to track and monitor, providing another step back from previous games, also not being helped by the control system.Space station walking is also pointless and akin to an FPS of the previous decade in terms of how moving around it feels, and of five years ago on how it looks. This is not a commend on the aesthetics of the models, but on the technical accomplishement of the engine for interiors. The fact that every single person you meet is just so ugly and so similar would make for a good lore item of how cloning brought the species to this state, but this is not offered anywhere and the strip clubs on stations do not seem to agree with a cloning reproduction society. Space station walking is just irrelevant and every one is the same as the other, as there are only three or four models reported as available (although to mee it felt more ilke two different ones).Trade is also completely new. Not only can you buy and sell items to people in stations when you walk in there, but now you can give commands to big trade ships to buy and sell between stations. The problem is that this is too slow, too little. In previous games, the trader ships could fit any product or raw material in the universe. Not so in this one, as they are specialized. Maybe there are others available later or someplace else that I have not seen, but then using the trade ships is extremely slow as you have to wait for them to dock (10 minutes or so), load (anything from 1 to 3 minutes), fly off (another 10 to 20 minutes depending on position in the sector), travel to the next sector (which is another 5 to 20 minutes), dock (10 minutes), unload their goods (another 1 to 3 minutes). All this must be done in real time.As if to drive the nail home, gone is S.E.T.A. which might have salvaged something from this. Time acceleration was always something that developer Egosoft have made a remark on as not being the end-all tool players were using it for. it does not surprise me that it came time to drop S.E.T.A now, nor that further comments have been made that it will NOT be comming in a future date. Real Time is the name of the game, but this is a single player game and not a multiplayer platform where time needs to be kept accurate for the sake of the community. This is a design decision that says Egosoft wants us to experience their game in real time, as if being afraid that using S.E.T.A. would make gamers bored after having finished their game so soon. Only that a true X game cannot end, as the end is only defined by the player, not the available options given by the developer.I fully acknowledge that this may have been intended as a new type of game, in which case it is not something I like and cannot recommend to anyone. If this is supposed to be the next X then I still do not like it as it is completely different to anything that ever made the X game what they were. Space is beautiful though!

												I wish I could say good things about this game, I really do. I purchased this at launch after visiting forums and discussing things with others and had high hopes, but due to some in game bugs and poor game controller support nothing really worked. The fact that my computer broke gave me a break to allow some updates to come out and let me reset my expectations. Now some updates have come out and I gave it some time coming back to it with a fixed computer. Only just, has the most recent patch allowed me to keymap a joystick correctly, somehow however, I have lost the ability to play in first person portions. Mouse and keyboard integration while using a third party controller has made making it past the tutorial stages an absolute nightmare. Before I could walk around but not fly the ship, now I can fly the ship but not walk around. Forget beta testing, this game still feels like it's in alpha... I want my money back at this point. I'll hold out that maybe one day this might be good, but this is just ridiculous.

												It's not very enjoyable in its current state with many show stopper or game breaking bugs. Hopefully they will begin working these things out. I'm not sure how many of them, almost all of them really, got past their testing. This is more like a mid beta release than a real release, it reflects bad on them. The objective location isn't helpful when you don't know what to do there.And there's many more but those are the ones that come to my mind when I explain why I've put down the game for the time being. I do hope that in time they patch... fix? the game to make it a fully enjoyable experience.

												I am a first-time player of the X series, and fully acknowledge that several fans of the series consider this game to not be one of the X series, but an attempt to make the game more accessible.At this time, I have not played X3 or any of the previous titles (though I have been highly recommended to do so).X Rebirth starts out just how you'd want, beautiful graphics, good physics, sandbox environment, some resemblance of a storyline. However, as several have noted the bugs in this release made the game ridiculous to play initially. I have heard that several of the bugs have been patched but I haven't given the game another chance since the first weekend I dedicated roughly 20-30 hours.After a few hours of getting acquainted, I found that I very quickly ran out of things to do. The game was sort of driving me along a storyline (which included several broken sections) but there was no clear direction on what the "end-game" content was meant to be. Sure, you can build stations, other ships, but you're limited to only one ship to fly? I bought this game thinking it was the "game to make EVE Online look horrible", but I later found out that is Star Citizen.Shame Steam doesn't offer refunds, this was a complete was of my money - and it clearly should've been marked as an early release of the game. A Metascore of 33 (the lowest of my library by far) speaks for itself as well. Save your money.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Stay away. Star far, far, away. You have been warned.Where to begin... actually, I have a good idea.Quite simply put, this game is unfinished. Beyond the plethora of bugs and performance issues, there aer many, many features that are simply not well implemented or unfinished. THERE IS NO RADAR ON A SPACE SIM GAME. That's something AWFULLY basic to leave out of a space sim.Trading is another excellent example of this. In order to trade in this game, you have to order your freighters to go around picking up or selling wares which takes ten or twenty minutes depending on the location or god forbid, you run into a bug where your freighter simply sits there and do nothing. However, for some unknown reason, Egosoft decided that a cancel trade order button is not necessary. Really? At this point, I don't even know if this is intentional design or just another checkmark on the growing list of unfinished features.Beyond key missing features, the state of the game itself feels unfinished as well. The truly awful looking character models look like they are placeholders until something better takes their place, and space scenery, while gorgeous, wavers upon closer examination as you fly up next to ships and stations and see generic, bland, I would say almost placeholder-like low-res textures.Adding in walk-in stations per requested below. There are only 3-4 presets in every system, which wouldn't be so bad in and of itself if the game did not force you to walk in stations for every other interaction. Picking up missions, dropping off missions, hiring marines, hiring pilots and officers. Couple that with the atrocious looking NPCs and you can see why almost no one likes this aspect of the game. The fact that the most popular mod is to REMOVE the need to walk in stations says volumes in and of itself. That being said, it can be a great platform for future mods, but in its current state, implementation, and restrictions? It is really bad.I have put hundred of hours in X3. While Egosoft had always said Rebirth is going to be a departure from the series, the pre-release promotion they did for the game is borderline fraud. Case in point, most of the features on its Steam page is missing or not working. The system requirement is a joke. I have a 4ghz i7, 16GB ram, and 7970 Crossfire and I consistently get 10fps in the game.tl;dr DON'T SUPPORT UNFINISHED GAME RELEASES

												I keep installing it, playing it, uninstalling it... I want to play it, I want to like it, but I just can't.Bought the game on release day and thought it was terrible. Slow, buggy, annoying characters, poor design... I kept trying it again, after each patch, and found the game to be still lacking... Still buggy, still fundmentally flawed. So I unistalled it (again) and waited to see what the next patch would bring.First off it started off with rumours of "something big in May". Then I started seeing some stuff about the beta of 2.0 and some videos of gameplay. The videos made the game look fantastic (but then they always did) and when 2.0 was finally release, I reinstalled and tried it again... Nope.. Still a mess.My first attempt was a restart of the campaign. Seemed to play alright, but i really can't stand that annoying cow that gets dumped on you in the first few seconds of the game... Seriously, whoever thought she would be a good character? She's the Jar Jar Binks of the X Universe.So settling on  the more open approach of free play I loaded it up and started doing passenger transfer missions. Everything was going fine, a decent frame rate of around 40-50 FPS, highways were "OK" (could still do with some work especially when flying with autopilot which seems to want to crash into every ship in the highway at every chance it gets) and I started making money. Even had a couple of small dogfights and came out ok... Then it happened! After undocking from a station the game suddenly started running like a slideshow at 3FPS and no apparent reason why. It was fine when I first entered the system, fine when I flew to the station and fine for the 3+ hours that I'd spent playing the game previously. But all of a sudden it became unplayable. Even the pause menu took a good few seconds to display when I pressed escape. So I quit with a few passing remarks about Egosoft qualty control and "cowboy programmers" and uninstalled.Wanting to try some of the other starts I reinstalled it a couple of days later and tried trader. Not being familiar with which stations give which wares in this new X Universe I was just wandering aimlessly from system to system to system, going back to ferrying passengers around and trying to work out where I need to buy various things. It doesn't seem as clear cut as X3 where you knew that Power Circle was the place to get power cells and sell them to the neighbouring stations and you could start making money from there and branching out into other things once you'd made some cash. After an hour or so I gave up.So I finally tried Mercenary. Followed the waypoints to that guy who offers the partol, escort or passneger mission, then starting looking for other mission to complete. Was playing fine until.... 3FPS, but this time after only an hour and a half of play.Honestly, I give up on it.

content:
Posted: May 23, 2014
												Not recommended... This is not the "X" game you are looking for...Firstly, let me stress that I am a massive fan of the previous "X" Games. When I saw "Rebirth" was due to be released I immediately found myself looking forward to getting lost in another massive, bustling galaxy with lots to see, do and buy. I always found the massive range of player useable ships meant I could always find something new to work toward purchasing and upgrading. Now, when I heard about Rebirth, and the ability to dock and walk around stations to trade, modernised graphics and a great new storyline campaign, I was ecstatic. I thought to myself "this is exactly the game I have been waiting for!". Unfortunately, when the game was first relased it received such appalling reviews that I did't even try it. I guessed (correctly I suppose) that if I waited a while then game-breaking bugs would be fixed, and the price would fall. So, with the release of the latest update, "Rebirth 2.0" which claims to have recitified the majority of faults and overhauled the gameplay based on player feedback (combined with the Steam promotion which was running at the time) I thought Rebirth might be worth a look. I was wrong...Visuals: Yes, it is pretty. Well... at least in space. Graphically this is a nice step up from the latest generation of X games, and is more or less what I had been expecting. However if you dock at a station, don't expect anything resembling realistic characters. Character models on the whole are grotesque, with extremely outdated visuals and horrible, frozen expressions. Stations themselves once you reach the interior, are simply cookie cutter copies of each other with very little variation at all. See one station, you've seen them all. At one stage of the storyline, an NPC aboard your ship exclaims "Wow, I've never seen a station like that before" (or words to that effect.) But as I clambered out of my ship, oh look it's the same docking bay/corridors/rooms as the previous 10. They're empty, lifeless, bland and generally uninteresting addtions to the game that in my opinion would have been better off ignored.Gameplay: Well... Bland. That seems to be the most commonly recurring word I think of when trying to accurately describe the majority of the game in fact. At first, flying around in your ship is reasonable fun as you take in the view and fly through the highways. But it gets old, fast. Firstly, the small to medium sized vessel you begin the game with is the only thing you will be flying. The "Albion Skunk" is yours for the duration. Sure, you can fit it with new weapons and engines as you'd expect, but you cannot purchase or fly other ships, even though you may own them and hire crew to fly them for you. And as flexible as this ship is, I can't help but long for the days of being able to pilot just about any ship I could find. I didn't get any sense of achievement or reward being stuck with the same, rather bland (there's that word again) ship throughout. Secondly, the campaign itself. I admit, I completely abandoned this after around 4 hours. I kept thinking something wonderful would be just around the corner, however I spent the entire time flying through numerous sectors in which there was nothing to see, to numerous stations in which there was nothing to do. Once there, I would talk to one of the numerous copy/paste NPCs who would then send me to do the same at another station. There is no longer any form of time dilation to speed up travel, you're stuck staring at space. On the whole, I think the biggest issue with this iteration is simply that there is nothing to DO... You spend your time floating meaninglessly through space filled with meaningless empty characters with no purpose. The large majority (and I'm really not exaggerating here) of NPC's will simply fly in circles without any concern for the world around them. I really, really wanted to like this game. And I tried, I really did. Unfortunately, it just wasn't to be. I am sorely disappointed, even after going in with low expectations following other poor reviews. Take my advice, and spend your money elsewhere.

content:
Posted: April 24
												A complete departure that looks and plays worse than the older games. Fans will hate it, new players will think it's awful.The game has completely changed (hence the name), and for the worst. It used to be a technical marvel with solid gameplay, now it's another generic, stereotypical low budget obscure game.Everything about it is worse than even X2, which was released in 2003. Gameplay is clunky; interiors, characters, all look like they came from 2001; even the backdrops of planets and stars look less amazing; the voice acting is actually worse; the music isn't as good as it used to, and one mini-game has a stereotypical techno-ish soundtrack that loops every 3 seconds, and not even properly, so it skips.X3 had 100, 150 sectors. This game basically has 4 different backdrops. FOUR. Four very large maps, but pointlessly large, they could've stuffed it all into a smaller space.Getting from place to place is no longer by jump gates, but you fly through 'highways'. No longer do you immediately get where you want to go, but you must 'drive' down these highways for 10, 20 seconds, longer. Combat is no longer smooth and dramatic and certainly no sexy battles going on here. Even the pilots aren't bothered, literally saying stuff like "yup I felt that" rather than screaming as they face death.Trading requires more douching around. You can now walk in stations, but they all look the same. You can talk to people... well no, you can't talk to people. You can click on them and get them to show their wares or hire them or whatever, and on occasion you can engage in 'small talk' if they blurt something out loud about one of 4 subjects. Same quotes, same answers, just to get a little discount or info you could live without. The sitting-in-a-ship-reading-news-and-hearing-announcements from previous games were far more immersive.The poor production values and slow (even for the X series!) gameplay ruin the story mode, I was not invested in any way.Old games like X2 and Freelancer, budget games like Darkstar One, even recent games like No Man's Sky or that one space level from Call of Battlefield do it so much better.

												This game is in the works.  Needs a better actress for Yisha (Your very ANNOYING copilot).  Going on stations, boring.  The other people in FP visitations are dry, and lack vitality.  Capital ships NEED bridges, not landing pads.  Gameplay is pretty cool when you can actially command from the cap ship.  The skunk (your ship) is explorable, but bland and also does not feel like it has personality, let alone function or life outside the actual controls in the front.  The concept of this game is AWESOME.  The downfall right now is lack of function of station visitations, general lifeless feel from NPCs, and the acting.  The narration from the ship computer (and station announcement lady) are also read as though they didnt bother to have any quality control overview.  The economy is still a mess, there is a general lack of any goal other than to build a capship, or whatnot and maybe a space station.  As far as exploration, you wont be finding any actual adventure other than beautiful scenery outside of the main story plot.  All the women look butch.  And act butch.  This game was built for people who like strategy games and mercantile activities, but fighting, trading and exploring is just plain AWEFUL.  If I were to make any recommendations to the development of this release, it would be to go back and get better actors.  Better animations for NPCs, add capship bridges, and more functions to the ships and bridges, and mini adventure content, and redo the textures on stations and keep getting the economy repaired.  the devs do a great job, but only as of now have catered to merchants.  What they offer explorers, fighters, and thinkers is so narrow, and it takes away from the game dramatically.  I asm not sure that the developers really care to address these VERY important character flaws of their baby, because I believe they think they will please us players somehow eventually.  People are still very unhappy about this game, and yes it had a bad launch, but they will not gain momentum with gamers unless they BALANCE their efforts.  So far, traders get %90.  And since freelook, no immersive features added,  I give this game a thumbs up, but I EXPECT the devs not only repair bugs and add a few features but create a more immersive atmosphere, by getting these NPCs and missions some more flavor.  More "functions"  more "interactions on ships and stations"

content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
												First Review of 3.0 and DLC3.0 and DLC are well done. These changes and improvements are EXACTLY the thing, Rebirth needed. Features like crafting, lockboxes, secret collections etc. made the THINK part complete for the first time- now, collecting items and exploring the inner part of a station makes much more sense- it's not longer unuseful and boring after a short time. Secret boxes you can find in the universe improved the long time playing- it is really hard to find everything for every collection, and made exploring the universe much more exiting.I'm also exited about the little things you did to make the life of gamers easier- features like running and the clickable map where overdue. Rebirth becomes more and more the game we expected once.The DLC shows, that Rebirth can also deal with missing local highways. Interesting fact is the pathfinding with navi-barks- an alternate way of pathfinding to give the player the opportunity to get safe through dangerous regions. Ah, of course, these dangerous nebulae- so, finally, genius ideas from 'X2-the threat' get their comeback...The Teladi stations have their unique teladian design- even the 'teladian green' from Helge T. Kauz' novels. Nice little thing is the form of the new Teladi ships- it's like the top of an egg and reminds me of Nopileos beloved ship known from the novel Nopileos''- a 'eggy' design bound deep in teladi background story from Helges books. Great! And of course, it's also nostalgic (in a good way) to see known shipnames from the X game history coming back- like phoenix and falcon.But of course, there are still hair-raising problems, especially in ship moving. for example the thing with local highways and bigger ships. Every time, you attack a capital, it tries to fly into a highway- ok, good way to prevent small ships from hiding in nishes, but also a big problem for attacking/boarding them (highway tube protects the ship)! It also happens often that such large ships just fly through highway streams following their path, because in normal flight, they ignore them! NPC Ships just fly through the intruder, but the playership hits it and pops out of the highway. It would make more sense, when larger ships avoid local highways and probably bounce back when they hit them (without getting damage).The new boarding concept is ok- but it is not well balanced. I had to destroy nearly EVERY drone and surface element on a Titurel to succeed- so It takes hours for the ship to get the engines repaired and fly to a shipyard to get repaired or sold. Train the marines is a nice way because it's realistic and not as expensive as to buy them- but I think buying Elites and Veterans is still ok, the price is high enough to make training still a sinful option- and the need boarding smaller ships first can be a problem for someone who wants to board only criminal elements like reivers (not much size m and l ships there).Balancing in general is still a huge problem. And it gets worser and worser. With all criminal factions using larger ships like Titurels (an XL, well armed, Freighter), there are too few protecting units left, even in Omicron Lyrae, intended as the safest of the Systems. After playing a while, many stations have already broken parts because large ships destroyed them without being stopped by any allied XL ship. No save areas left, even in OL. It should be possible to restrict them to only border or less save sectors to get regions, safer than others. In DeVries nearly every landing platform outside of 'glaring truth' is destroyed- I know, it's planned as dangerous place, and you wanted more action, but this destroys every NPC trade left in DV! An option would be that reivers just attack ships and not stations- or only larger Titurels attack stations. Or let more of the faction ships protect their property. But something must be done.Exept for these Problems still remaining, 3.0 and DLC are big steps in the right direction. After all, Rebirth turns to everything we dream for- thank you for that!greetings, MJ Fire

												 To be honest I really wanted to like this game. I even got it against my better judgement to the thoughts of 'maybe it's not as bad as they say it is.' 'maybe they just aren't adjusting to the new way the game plays' and 'maybe it has improved over time to the point where it is as enjoyable as previous games in the series'. I am very sorry to report that this is just not the case.  In some ways, I would have prefered it if they simply copied and pasted the X-3 universe, tweaked it a bit by adding a few new systems and adding better economy and then just selling THAT as a new game. At least I'd of probably enjoyed that.That's not totally fair though, they DID make an effort, they just got it terribly wrong. In absolute fairness, I found that the storyline by itself had improved from previous X-games. and even though the one ship deal did put me off playing for a while, I got used to that. But every other aspect about it from the way it looks to the way it moves and that way it performs just... irritates me to no end... especially when I know these people can produce games such as X-3 and X-2. Let that serve as a warning to anyone looking to buy. They have lost a lot of fan support because of this... including mine. Sure they all had their own faults too but simply put... I liked those games, I can play X2 and X3 for days, weeks, even months at a time, I can barely just about manage to force myself to put up with X-rebirth for maybe a few hours.

Posted: June 8, 2016
												As many other people have already pointed out, X-Rebirth has come a very long way.  I was one of many who purchased the game on launch and felt robbed of my money at the time.  If steam refunds were a thing back then I would have certainly asked for one.  In a way, the lack of steam's refund policy allowed me to hold onto the game until the point where it is today.  Egosoft has not given up or abandoned their project and has taken many of the necessary steps to improve the game.  They encourage ideas and actually seem to listen to what their customers want in the game.  Optimization was terrible at first launch.  The game didn't feel smooth and was quite laggy.  Since then the game is far better and lag is fortunately a thing of the past.  The campaign is ok...at best.  A lot of important points about the game are left out and some things are far easier in the campaign than they actually are in freeplay.  The best way to learn about the game is to use forums and the wiki.  They have been very helpful to me.  Please understand that many of the negative reviews of this game are from a long time ago and do not accurately portray the game as it is now.  With all of that said I would say the game is decent overall.  Personally, I wouldn't pay full price but I would buy it if it were on sale.  As for the DLC, the same can be said.

Do with that as you wish.The short time I played this game in its free weekend left me frustrated above anything else. If one were to ignore the terrible dialog and voice acting, the game just plays horribly. The first mission is supposedly a tutorial, but it was probably the most unintuative mess I've ever seen. Nothing is explained properly. The entire UI is utterly confusing and your current goals (if any) are not easily found, let alone marked. I had to travel to a station and then dock.Firstly there is apparently some sort of highway system that acts as a 'current' through empty space. The way things are marked in space I first tried to go around this because I thought my objective was behind it. Eventually I figured out I had to go into it.Arriving at the station is where the real fun began. It took me absolute ages to figure out how docking worked. It took Google to explain to me that mousing over a service and pressing F comes up with a contextual menu. Holy♥♥♥♥♥♥how hard would it have been to explain this in the game? And even then it works like absolutely♥♥♥♥♥♥ Why can't I click on something to get that menu?Once I was docked the mechanic needed parts to fix my ship. Parts that were stored in a cabinet. His own cabinet, which he was standing right next to. But for some reason it was still MY job to get the parts from HIS cabinet. This is where I said '♥♥♥♥ it' and just closed the game. The game reeks of bad design in ever corner and playing it any further would have just left me even more frustrated. Maybe if you get past all this it could be a fun game, but it's just really badly designed. Certainly not something I would spend any amount of money on with the first 30 minutes of gameplay being this bad.

content:
Posted: March 20, 2015
												Ok, so I bought this game over the weekend and haven't really been able to put it down. Why?, I will try to explain...I am not familiar with the franchise or any games of this particular genre. I am also aware of the appauling state this game was released in and the plethora of negative reviews and dissapointed fans this game has racked up since release. I have not experienced the bugs to the extent of those that purchased the game on release, so I don't share the same experience. But as a modern gamer I can certainly relate to the extreme dissapointment that these fans have experienced in games like Rome 2. But at the end of the day, I felt compelled to write a review, probably because of my contrarian nature in which I felt that this game in it's current state is not represented properly. It's a real gem! The work the devs have put into revitalising this game has to be commended, albeit a year too late.. But the very fact that they are still fully supporting and working on the game vigorously shows commitment, which is a worthy trait in a developer in this day and age. Ok, now for my review.STORY:You start off as a sort of space vagabond who comes across a ship which apparently has quite a history, and affectionately called the 'Albion Skunk'. Your copilot, a sexy space babe who coincidentally has some high up connections  and political ties stumbles into your ship and accompanies you throughout the game. Ok that's more or less it for story. The rest is a sort of political/ factional scenario whose narrative has been built up over previous games. Think Star Trek/ Star Wars/ LOTR/Game Of Thrones typical factional allegiances and disputes and you'll come somewhat close. In other words it perpetuates the racial typecasting and stereotypes we have all come to know and love in todays society.GAMEPLAY:The thing I love about spaceships is the freedom of movement in 3d space. In my opinion it can't be fully realised with just a mouse and keyboard. I use a G13 in which the thumbstick controls my steering, and the x/y strafe movement is controlled by the WSAD keys on the G13. Gun aiming and general browsing through my ships peripherals is done with the mouse. Throttle is controlled by the rollerball on the mouse. This enables a deeper control which unwittingly adds another layer of immersion to the game. Again, coming from a background not familiar with these type of games it's all the more a savouring experience for me. Last game I played like this was perhaps 'Descent 3' way back when...You really feel that you are a pilot and develop a bond with your ship. Every upgrade you purchase for your ship, be it engine type or shield type, you tailor towards your play style. The variety of upgrades to the ship specifically is somewhat lacking. But bare with it, as there are other dimensions and upgrades beyond mere shield/ weapon/ engine types. Enter the drones.. Ok these wonderful little companions come in two flavors: URV (perhaps not the correct term for what these vehicles actually do in this game but thats what they call them) which you launch and they more or less go about doing their thing, and ROV drones which you personally control through a VR helmet from within your ship. There are Assassin drones, Shield drones, Hacking drones, Combat drones, Worker drones (for your cap ships or freighters). Wanna be a space pirate? Load up a few Trojan drones, upgrade your scanning tech, skirt to the edge of the sector/ asteroid belt or mining colony/ or just near a faction you want to weaken or don't like, wait for freighters to loot, scan the cargo, send in your drone from a distance, hack the cargo doors on the ship so the freighter drops its loot. Have your freighter parked up nearby with a stack of collector drones, pickup the goods, sell them to your favored faction.Want to be a raider? Load up a crew of space Vets, hire engineers/ captains/ marines, asssault an enemy frigate, board and hijack disabled vessels. Sell them off to your favored faction or add them to your personal fleet.Want to be a trader? Scan stations and chatup NPC's for discounts and commisions, install trade agents onboard every station so you can keep up to date with buy and sell offers and bids. Build up a database of trade offers and identify defecits in supply and demand. Get yourself a freighter and automate trade between stations, buying low and selling high, cornering the market and running your competitors into the ground. This sort of playstyle sits so well with me. It plays into the faction synergies and economics of the game so perfectly and  way better than any other game out there currently, it's almost a revolution in this genre. Granted, the stations and jobs are rather generic and so are the NPC's which I hope the dev's improve upon, but it doesn't matter so much because of the METAGAME. The jobs themselves come in a variety which have been improved upon in recent patches. You can do taxi missions, station protection missions, special envoy missions, sabotage enemy billboard missions, and new relic and treasure hunt missions to name just a few.Then there is the station/ fleet and empire building part of the game. WOW, this is immense. You build your corporate empire in which ever manner you see fit. You can build your own stations, construct your own wares, hiring your own staff, who through quite sophisticated AI manage themselves. You can assign budgets, delegate pilots and ships like freighters to managers who will then go on to use those resources you assigned them to defend themselves if attacked or to go and buy a resource they need from a station. The staff themselves have statistics and attributes that can be improved upon through recently added seminars.. Can you begin to fathom the scope of this game? GRAPHICS:Beautiful, albeit a bit generic in terms of stations and NPC's. The different space locals are quite impressive, be it near a sun where you can see the Solar gunk being ejected from the surface, or destroyed planets and moons, all make for different regions in space, and does not make it feel like you are in empty space all of the time. Make sure your rig is sufficient to crank up anti aliasing or you'll be in jaggy town deluxe due to many structures popping up in the emptyness of space. Allot of outlines and silhouettes, so aliasing becomes a necessity. I run the game on full ultra settings with 4x anti aliasing and SSAO set to low. A trick I found to most games and this one in particular is that if you turn AA up turn AF down or off. Do this through your card settings and set the game to control af settings as it has none. This increases performance in many games at the expense of sharper textures which is sort of fixed by increasing AA in itself.But yeah the ships look fabulous, and new ones have been added since release, so thats a positive thing. Theres rows of traffic near stations, queues to get onto the interstellar highways. Combat feels good, with pretty explosions and effects. Not an amazing array of different weapon types like some games but enough to keep it fresh looking. CONCLUSION:What this game attempts and somewhat pulls off is commendable. This game does combat and battles well, but that's not what it is. Information is so valuable in this game. You find yourself pulling up in a sector, looking at the radar and analysing ships and cargo, what they're carrying, which faction they belong too,  what class ships are accompanying, what kind of armament they are sporting etc.. Either just to get a trade or power picture or sussing out who's carrying a juicy payload worth robbing. All through your ships onboard computer. It generally touches base with everything you'd want in an open universe exploration game with an almost limitless scope, and now it seems in this stage to be in a working state. If you like these sort of games, wait for the next sale and buy it with no second thoughts.

												This is my first game in X series. I have no idea why people dislike it so much.It, indeed, gives yo an opportunity to play however you like. You can earn money from your stations or be a pirate or a taxi driver. It is fun to capture ships and steal cargo from storages without being caught. Feel yourself like Han Solo when police scans your full of contraband ship and you sit with a poker face, deciding is it better to drop something and slip away or download the last save.Ofc this game is not about being a pirate. There is simply no way to waste money if you do not build your own economy. I do not enjoy all that kind of things so I dropped the game for now.I also see no reason to hate Albion Skunk, the only ship you can pilot. Since it is possible to change the view of the cockpit I did not get bored of a view of the ship. Maybe I just do not care how my ship looks like but how it flies.One thing is simply wonderful about this game is that it has so many tiny things which make it look real - you can see how cargo is transfered from ship on a tiny drones, police will get worried if they know that a station is being hacked, Lots of small ships cycle around stations and indeed carry stuff from one place to another. And, oh, people are not polite at all! They ask you to "boil your head" sometimes.I'd call this game wonderful if it had better music, voices, more integrated design of menues and way more effects in space. Come on! Ships don't even do a sound when jumping! I can also say that the surroundings are more close to a "real" space - they are boring.Another drawback is that it is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ hard to play the game for the first time. Not only because inbuilt tutorial does not tell even a half of the information but because there is absolutely no information on the internet. You have to guess or read dozens of forums since there is no good wiki for this game.So, I still recommend the game. I would not call it "a must have" but it is great to have fun in space.

												Tl;Dr - I'd give X Rebirth an 8 out of 10. It's an incredibly fun, diverse game with plenty of things to do. The Steam reviews do not represent the game in its current state.Let me start by saying this to prospective buyers; X Rebirth is NOT X4. It's a game set in the X universe, and aspired to be a new game entirely - Something which I think it has done very, very well.You can only fly one ship. This ship is virtually your own Millennium Falcon - It's unique, incredibly powerful, and quite customizable, and is basically a few different ships in one package. If you were able to fly multiple types of ships, you'd probably go for this one every time.Now, onto the review.You'll notice that X Rebirth has a very low score on Steam. Don't judge a book by its cover - Most of these scores were given around the time of v1.0, or were given by people who don't read up on a game before they buy it.X Rebirth 1.0 was a shoddy mess, virtually an early beta of a game with clunky mechanics, bad voice acting, and more glitches than you could possibly imagine. Most people dropped X Rebirth straight off the bat, gave it a bad review, and never looked back.Not long after that, however, 2.0 came out and completely revolutionized the game. Everything was streamlined and most of the problems fixed, and the game became more or less playable, and even pretty enjoyable. A few patches later and the game was pretty much how you'd expect a game to be at launch, with hundreds upon hundreds of hours of content (If you're a creative person) and lots of ways to make your empire what you want it to be - If you want an empire at all, that is.The story was honestly not that compelling, but there's plenty of reasons to play it as it confers unique bonuses on certain systems that free play simply would not, such as more diverse economies in certain systems.3.0 rolled around at the end of 2014, only a year after the game's release, and set the bar higher than before. The game became much, much more fun, now with a total of 5 systems to explore (Note that each system has multiple sectors, each of which is bigger than a system from previous X games) as well as dozens of factions to meet, hundreds of ships and stations to build and use, and wares to mine, manufacture, and trade.X Rebirth today is an incredibly fun game. A single save could take hundreds of hours of your time as you build yourself an empire in a system. You could start a new game and take a completely different route, giving you hundreds more hours of gameplay as you make a name for yourself elsewhere. The sky's the limit with your choices in X Rebirth.While there are still a few glitches and bad mechanics to the game, most of it has been smoothed out. With the upcoming Home of Light DLC, the world is set to almost double in size and have many new factions to play with.If you're looking for X4, don't bother with X Rebirth. If you're looking for a new and fun space business and combat sim that'll provide hours of fun, then X Rebirth is the game for you.

If the pros are good enough, the cons don't matter.If you like space rpg's, moderate micro management (immersion for me), exploring (space as well as game systems and mechanics), and a true sandbox experience where if you put in the time and effort to experiment and reasearch different gameplay options, then this game is for you. It is for me. Having a lot of fun. Pirate, Hacker, Fleet Captain, Trader....lots of ways to play, some simple straight up shooter, some deep, complex gamestyles.I will just add the the devs and community's passion for the game is a BIG plus for me. Seems like updates and mods are still happening, even after all this time. I am confident this will not be abandoned for a long time (Tho if it was, it would STILL be worth it). It truely just keeps getting better.Hope this helps those on the fence. Buy it. It'll be a game you return to again and again.

Posted: October 17, 2014
												This was supposed to be an improvement over previous versions, but other than the graphics, soundtrack and the return of a visible and usefull cockpit it does not live up to the expectations, nor the X title.First of all your immediate surroundings look cramped, and I'm not talking about the ship interior... It used to be a lot more spaced out and felt more of...well...space... The upscaling of the stations certainly did not do the game any good as well, as it only contributes to that same feeling. It really feels as though your in the middle of a concert than in space.Second, the controls...I don't know what came over the developers when figuring this out, but after all the hard work they put in the X3 engine I really expected more. I found it near impossible to target a station to dock with, not to mention it being counter-intuitive; While you could click on a ship in the distance to target, get info, whatever, on stations that simply doesn't work. The menu system was a lot sleaker and less cumbersome as well, it reacted a lot faster without all the fancy animations / transitions and the general feel complemented the game as a whole. And although I like the idea of a board computer that gives that feeling of your character actually interacting with a computer, unless you run at a very high resolution it is very difficult to actually read what it's displaying (played on 1280x800).Last but not least, the lanes...why...why not have sectors overlap eachother so you don't need all that fancy stuff, or load based on the ships radar distance...there are so many alternatives to using jump gates (if that was the goal) that are not so much of a nuisance.I have played every X game, and have loved every single one of them, regardless of the terrible characters and all that; That somehow became part of the charm. But I seriously believe this to be a big mistake made by EgoSoft. If they wanted to make an engine / game that looked and felt so immensely different from the rest of the X series, they should really have experimented with some arbitrary new title that has nothing to do with it; A once off game that may have the potential to grow into an entirely new series, or merge with the X series at a later time, whatever. It would have been a lot better than take a succesfull series and throw it down the toilet like this.

content:
Posted: March 17, 2015
												   X Rebirth is significantly different than X3.  I definitely like the graphics quality.  The fact that the game is played at 2 different levels is an interesting approach.  Politics seems a little more stable than in X3 as total war until complete annihilation is not declared as you scratch a station.  I miss the fact that it was possible in X3 to personally fly any ships in the galaxy.  I am tired of being called a skunk and this ship is not impressive in no way. It gets easily shot even after upgrading and it is hard to hit anything with it.  After 25 hours trying to figure out the mechanics of the game, I am barely able to trade, defend and manage anything.  The trading system requires that you own a station in order to do anything significant.  I find it hard to understand why I need to be soo close to docking points to only get very limited information. (even after upgrades)  I would assume that a trading dock would advertise what it is doing, right???  It is strange how everyone knows everything about the galaxy while I can barely remember anything about the station I visited.  Just one word I want to add, sunglasses, they were discovered millenniums ago... they seem to have forgotten about this very advanced technology.  It kills the graphics quality, sad.   I am complaining a lot, but I am sure I will finally get through the very complex mechanics of this game.  I think there is interesting ideas about it, I would simply appreciate ameliorations on the trading system.

												CONSIDER THIS AN PRE-RELEASE CONSOLE PORT.I was so excited to play this game, I loved the earlier X games and this looked amazing.It's not what i was expecting: The controls have been simplified, it's been designed to use a gamepad.Walking around space stations reminds me of budget games from 10 years ago and is just a time waster. Now many missions and functions need you to deal with it even if you don't want to.Many basic functions such as buying some trade goods is a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ You need to go through twice as many menus as earlier games to do even basic trades or orders, oh and those are bugged and don't work half the time anyway.The game was not completed on release. Dozens of issues have been identified like terrible performance, bugged ai, incompletable plot missions and non working key binds.There is ample proof out there that this was originally to be an xbox 360 title, people have found 360 coding and file names in the game already and the controls definately back this theory up.Its not a 100% terrible game though, but will take weeks or maybe months to be playable and will probably never match X3:AP modded.Definately not worth $50 at the moment. It could one day be fun, I'm not angry egosoft.... just disappointed.

												I had VERY high hopes for this game. Unfortunately, the game is plagued with bugs and poor design choices. The graphics and voice acting are what one might expect from a nintendo 64 game. The pixel shaded graphics are a huge step in the wrong direction; The X3TC and X3AP games had much better graphics. The game engine is terribly unoptimised, so even decent systems will experience low frame rates.The whole experience seems very unpolished and unsophisticated with lackluster design. The game does have potential for some very addictive qualities, but I can't recommend this game until Egosoft releases some major patches and perhaps even bonus content. In its current state, I'd have to give it a 5 out of 10.

Makes me wonder if it will ever make it to final version. This time I find things have become very time consuming in many places and some missions are bugged. The rigged asteriods ones mostly. Some missions say no time restraint but if you take to long to go talk to someone or something like that it cancels out. The captureing of ships has become somewhat of a mystery to me but since more missions provide 1 million+ payouts I find I dont care much for doing any captureing anymore. Highways still suck, Walking in stations still suck, walking anywhere still sucks. The game is much more stable for the camp. and building a empire in non story mode. content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
												First let me mention this game is much better with a few mods which you can get from the workshop or nexusmods. I do like this game but my review focuses more on what I don't like about it. You play as Ren Otani, pilot of the Albion Skunk (You can change the ship name!), a small space craft seemingly about the size of the Millennium Falcon. The engines, weapons, shield, ect can be upgraded. While you can't pilot any other vessel, you can acquire and issue commands to pretty much any class ship in the game. Your ships will also watch you get destroyed unless you tell them to attack each target one at a time or agro on every enemy they get in range of which will just cause unnecessary engagement. There really needs to be a "destroy anyone attacking your squad" option.I can see a lot of work went into this game and the scripting is impressive but it was obviously rushed out of production and nearly committed suicide by releasing in what was basically an unmarked beta stage. The bugs were so bad people started thinking if they couldn't find something it was a bug so they would just edit their save file as a fix. Currently most alleged "bugs" are due to "user error" and you should probably visit youtube before doing anything drastic like saved file editing but there are still a few minor bugs/issues.The biggest issue remaining in this game is the lack of in game information. Not only on how to do anything or where to start looking for a particular item but also info such as how a crew skill stats affect anything and the fact that you can't buy cargolifter drones from drone dealers but rather ship dealers at a shipyard.The economy is very much like elite dangerous but not quite as bad. NPC ships spawn in with cargo and deliver it to stations if you don't intervene. That cargo is then used to build parts to be sold to the quickest buyer, to build ships you order or NPC ships that do nothing but despawn shortly after construction. If a shipyard is constructing a (NPC) ship you can't use it for repairs, buying drones or anything. To make things worse if the shipyard doesn't have the resources for the ship it's building you can wait for a delivery if it ever happens or find and sell them the parts your self. Stations can't be obliterated or taken over, only badly damaged but they will get repaired after a time.The only station players can't build is a shipyard but fortunately there is a mod for that.I must mention once you acquire a missile on your ship, there is no way to remove it from the weapon list even after getting rid of it. Nothing like flipping through 10 types of missiles during the midst of combat looking for one you DO have. Also the same button for missile launching is used for scanning which is the equivalent of modifying a hand gun to function as a lighter when the safety is on. Additionally you will encounter a similar issue with your main guns, only two of which are deemed useful in combat but you may not want to toss your mining laser (oddly enough Elite Dangerous did the same thing).AI in this game must stand for "Artificial Idiots" because it has caused me several saved game reloads. Once my ship auto piloted it's way into the center of a station trapping me inside and another time my fleet of rihannas tried to jump through a warp gate all at the same time causing what looked like an Autobahn pile up.Graphics aren't bad for the most part but they do look years behind and nothing close to Elite Dangerous. The face textures for station crew however are kind of horrendous and everyone has a face only a mother could love.It's unfortunate there aren't more people playing this game because a broader audience would mean more modders and the modding community is what made this game enjoyable (rather than a tedious head ach) to me. But the bottom line is, if you can put up with a bit of a learning curve, enjoy long relaxing space flights and dogfight style combat intertwined with the strategy aspect of fleet commanding then this game is worth buying but best wait for a sale because $40 is a bit much unless they release a 4k graphical pack and more updates (last one being released Mar 13) to fix the things so many people are complaining about.

												Probably one of the poorest games I have ever played.I finally took the bait when it was on sale and update 3.50 was released.  The point being I bought into this at v3.50.For me, the game is dead by default.The whole idea of having to fly all over and around individual stations just to find a stinking missing is a game mechanic that is offputting beyond belief.I'd rather not have to faff about to be able to find something to do.To me the game was designed to be unfriendly and unwelcoming - I feel sorry for anyone who paid full price for this and lost their hard-earned money.The stats show the game has failed beyond imagination.4k+ reviews on Steam - 3k+ negative - 1k+ positive.The 'proof of the pudding' is with Teladi Outpost:31 positive reviews.  1k+ people defended this game, but only 31 people have given a positive rating for Teladi Outpost - so how many of the 1k+ people who gave Rebirth a positive score are still playing it?Patching the game won't help me enjoy it - the gameplay sucks for me and (I guess) for thousands of others.Gameplay is not slick - there's too much hunting around for something to do - too much pointless scanning stuff.Previous X3 games made it easy to see missions as you flew through a sector.Modders seem to have tried to save the game by releasing mods to try and overcome the train-wreck that the developers have created; however, will further updates to this game break mods that fix the game?I can see that there is a long-range scanner mod (Super Scanner) on the Workshop; however, the last comment anyone made was on 10th Feb 2015 to confirm it works with  3.2. So, although the game has been constantly patched, I wouldn't recommend it.I just don't understand the fun of flying super-close and all over a station, etc just to find missions and stuff.  How is that fun?  I seriously don't get it.  They added this in as a game-play feature - they designed it that way - it sucks.Give me X3 any day of the week over this.

Posted: December 29, 2014
												I'm on crossroads here, it's not as good as it should be and it's not bad as to not recommend it. So I'll opt to recommend with a raised finger. 5/10  Pros   You get to build your empire as in previous games, you build and upgrade your stations You have impact on the economy and have to think your strategy for profit as there are many ways how to do it Combat can be fun, you can destroy subsystems on ships, you can board ships, with 3.0 patch you have to train your marines from ground up capturing small weak ships first and going up from there Egosoft (developer) is constantly updating and expanding the game, so given time this game can be potentially great  Cons   To train your employees you need to participate in talking minigame on stations, they make you to listen to unskippable lines over and over and over again making very apparent that this is meant to waste your time Ship AI is terrible, sometimes it won't shoot, sometimes it will take ages to dock, sometimes it will fly through stations and they are slow and hard to command. If you leave the zone they start working well due to AI simulation.  Campaign is very short and after initial introduction and hyping ... let's say it's a cold shower in the end as if midway someone said holy s*hit we are shipping next week, WRAP IT UP! Game still feels unfinished on numerous fronts, DeVries system is stuck, construction sites without construction vessels are there forever to occupy building slots. You can't buy/sell or destroy stations. You can't capture sectors or influence politics in any way. I have no idea what your goals are beside becoming rich through economy and then there's nothing for you to spend it on other than more expansion. So I guess it's now mainly just economy building simulator with combat elements. There is little depth and complexity involved. Game and UI was designed around simple controller in mind, which makes it a chore to work with UI and many opportunities for control were left out because there aren't enough buttons for them on controllers. (Inventory management? Select multiple ships when giving commands?)

content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												Honestly, I want to like X Rebirth, I really do, but it's impossible. I've bought several early access (alpha) games on Steam in the past, and they were all in a better shape than X Rebirth is. The current state of things means you have to be a masochist to play the game, it's just frustrating and full of bugs.With another year of development, it might have been a decent enough game to stand on its own, but even if all the bugs were to be fixed, it will never really be able to live up to the expectations people who have played the previous X games have. It will never be able to compete with them as a sandbox game due to design decisions (really, one flyable ship?), it will never be able to compete as a trade/economy game since that entire part of the game is underdeveloped and completely devoid of any automation. Due to the horrid UI (to be honest, the X games have always had a horrid UI, requiring mods to use fully, but I thought that was going to be improved and streamlined for X Rebirth?), you can't really quickly see what's going on with your ships and the trades and so forth. Also due to the horrid UI, it will never compete with the old X games as a fleet simulator game either, since it's virtually impossible to organize and order your ships to do anything.All in all, don't buy X Rebirth yet. Wait until the bugs are fixed (if ever) and buy it when it's cheaper and try to play it at its own merits, and not an X game. Hopefully Egosoft will realize their folly and release a proper X game in the future.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												X: Rebirth is not an X series game. If you are trying to buy it while expecting such, dont. It is simply unsatisfying to play if you are looking for anything more complex than a space shooter.The developers spent 7 years working on the game to release for console, so the interface, options, and controls suffer from that design decision. As of this review, there is no way to target enemies besides clicking on them, all the menus are radial and difficult to navigate, and overall the performace of the game, even on high-end rigs, is poor.Being stuck in the same ship the entire game (The Albion Skunk, endearing..) is unsatisfying, especially when you see all the other cool looking ships flying around. Your co-pilot is annoying as humanly possible, your ship is invulnerable if you activate a drone, and you cannot carry any cargo inside of it. You have to hire other people to fly your other ships and carry cargo for you, and they have to be the most ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ pilots ever.The combat is weak and unchallenging. Enemies have spawned inside other ships and inside stations on several occasions, or they will just spawn in empty space and sit there, doing nothing as you blow them up. Though, why you would blow them up is a mystery, as they never shoot at you.The only good thing about the game is that stations look and feel truly alive and massive, with tons of npc ships flying around them and giving them satisfying feel. Unfortunately even this is ruined as the developers turned it into a minigame, making you fly and look at every inch of these massive stations to get missions and discounts. I won't even go into detail about docking and walking around inside of them, as that has to be the absolute worst part of the game, and you should live in fear of it. Overall, this is not an X game in the slightest, and was released in a state not fit for human consumption. Do not buy, and do not support a company that releases games in such a state. Everyone will tell you that the modders will fix it, or that the company will, and that is not an acceptable excuse for such a mess. Developers need to make functional, fun games, not engines and wait for the modders.

I've been a fan of X franchise for a long time, so I was expecting a failed release and didn't let my hope go down. With 3.5 release, I've decided to give it one more try. 												Not that you haven't heard this already if you've paid attention to what people say about this game, but its bugs have effectively stalled any hope of playing this game according to its hype.I'm sure Egosoft will resolve the issues, but in the meantime, $50 is an awful lot of money to pay for a game that feels very much like it's still in Beta. The controls are not too hard to use, giving you very full control over all directions to which your ship may move.Space graphics are nice, even if the in-person graphics seem a trifle outdated (walking around a station, most of the characters stand in one place, like manniquins, waiting for you to pester them). content:
Posted: November 22, 2013
												=== Post 2.0 ===I've spent about an hour with the game post 2.0. So far, I am impressed at the sheer number of improvements, I can actually play the game at a more reasonable frame rate (although it still drops below 40 every now and again, especially in the busier sectors). As for the game itself, it’s still single ship – which I don’t mind all that much as long as you can really fit that ship to your needs, something that the original version of the game failed at, This also has been improved upon slightly with the launch of 2.0, I’m very happy to see that the devs are heading in the right direction, but it is still not perfect by any stretch of the imagination.So far I love the new cockpits, especially the mercenary cockpit – an enhanced field of view is very much appreciated.They seem to have made improvements to the traders and cap-ships in general, I’ve seen a couple while flying around the universe – they don’t seem as stuck, lifeless and stupid as the original release – from what I could tell traders were actually trading, combat/defence cap-ships would seek out and destroy enemy craft in the sector and the occurrence of stacks of stuck trade ships in a sector seem to be eliminated.Combat feels a little more difficult – a welcome change, It’s nice to actually feel threatened while engaging a wing of fighters.Dogfighting, while still possible, is a little less reasonable in the Skunk now, forcing a more tactical approach to combat, you can’t just wade in through cap-ships and fighters alike and expect to just survive everything – although that could just be my joystick coming to the end of its life.My Verdict: So far so good, improvements are most welcome, it’s great to see Ego working out these issues and (as always) releasing free content and while the original game was pretty unplayable and hurt fans of the series a quite a bit, it’s nice to see Egosoft not give up on it and just move on to another cashgrab.Overall – I’d recommend this if it is on sale and you found x2 The Threat and x3 Reunion a too complex and daunting but still love space sims. If you can push past some of the questionable design decisions that surely will be phased out over time I think you could find an enjoyable experience in here – one piece of advice though, treat the campaign as a glorified tutorial and go into free play or one of the alt-starts to really experiment and have fun with the game.=== Pre 2.0 review ===A very rocky launch, needs a great deal of fixes, but this might make a good base for future X games. Regardless of what reviews might say I enjoyed this, however progress on patches is too slow. Possibly wait untill they fix the game? Or rather wait for their next ones --- may be more worthwhile.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2014
												So you can see that I waited a good while before reviewing this game. I gave the developers time to fix the myriad of experience-killing glitches. I gave them time to fix the game-breaking bugs. It's hopeless at this point. Even if they finally manage to fix the TERRIBLE performance issues on high-end gaming systems, and even if they fix all of the critical flaws in the game, AND even if they go so far as to fix the nearly broken interface -- it won't solve the underlying problem. What is the underlying problem? The basic gameplay is bad. It's just a bad game.Despite some decent ideas and nice-looking visuals (that won't run past 25FPS on my high-end system no matter what I do, a known bug), the game itself just simply isn't good. No matter how much you want to enjoy that classic X3 experience, or how much you want to enjoy a modern space simulator, this isn't the game for you. If you liked X3, don't buy this game. If you like space simulators, don't buy this game. If you like video games, don't buy this game. It has won a place in the hearts of many gamers for being their WORST GAME PURCHASE OF 2013. It is certainly, without question, the worst game purchase I've ever made. Yes, I've purchased some bad games, but never have I paid $50 for a new game and found it so utterly and completely disappointing. Where to begin? Well, the graphics, while decent, are plagued with such terrible slow-down and framerate issues as to be nearly unplayable. The story is tepid at best, with no real attraction. Don't expect the story to pull you in. The characters and voice acting are passable at best, laughably bad at worst. Expect to see the same character models and hear the same voices over, and over, and over. Cut-and-paste characters and space stations are the norm. You'll become very familiar with the two basic layouts you'll encounter dozens upon dozens of times. The music is quite decent, as it does what a good space combat simulator sound track should do -- it creates a nice "cosmic" atmosphere. Nothing that draws your attention too much, but makes you feel like you're in space. The sound FX are also quite decent for the most part, nothing too bad.The gameplay... It's just bad. You can feel like there's a good game deep inside this beast somewhere, but it just can't find it's way out. An attempt to make the game controller-friendly has needlessly obfuscated the interface. Many critical and commonly used functions are buried deep in menus, and you often find that you have to go here or there within the game world just to issue a simplistic command. The "cockpit" that was so painstakingly crafted serves to do little more than just eat up system resources and obscure the screen -- it's not even a HUD integration, it's just a needless visual distraction and resource hog. Whether you use mouse or keyboard, the interface is bad -- just bad. You want some great advice that you'd regret not following? Do not even consider buying this game. Don't look at it, don't watch videos of it, don't make any attempt to think that any amount of patching could fix this mess. It's a broken, clunky, frustrating mess of a game, but it commits the sin of looking like something decent to the uninformed. Consider yourself informed -- don't buy it. DO NOT BUY IT.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2014
												So you can see that I waited a good while before reviewing this game. I gave the developers time to fix the myriad of experience-killing glitches. I gave them time to fix the game-breaking bugs. It's hopeless at this point. Even if they finally manage to fix the TERRIBLE performance issues on high-end gaming systems, and even if they fix all of the critical flaws in the game, AND even if they go so far as to fix the nearly broken interface -- it won't solve the underlying problem. What is the underlying problem? The basic gameplay is bad. It's just a bad game.Despite some decent ideas and nice-looking visuals (that won't run past 25FPS on my high-end system no matter what I do, a known bug), the game itself just simply isn't good. No matter how much you want to enjoy that classic X3 experience, or how much you want to enjoy a modern space simulator, this isn't the game for you. If you liked X3, don't buy this game. If you like space simulators, don't buy this game. If you like video games, don't buy this game. It has won a place in the hearts of many gamers for being their WORST GAME PURCHASE OF 2013. It is certainly, without question, the worst game purchase I've ever made. Yes, I've purchased some bad games, but never have I paid $50 for a new game and found it so utterly and completely disappointing. Where to begin? Well, the graphics, while decent, are plagued with such terrible slow-down and framerate issues as to be nearly unplayable. The story is tepid at best, with no real attraction. Don't expect the story to pull you in. The characters and voice acting are passable at best, laughably bad at worst. Expect to see the same character models and hear the same voices over, and over, and over. Cut-and-paste characters and space stations are the norm. You'll become very familiar with the two basic layouts you'll encounter dozens upon dozens of times. The music is quite decent, as it does what a good space combat simulator sound track should do -- it creates a nice "cosmic" atmosphere. Nothing that draws your attention too much, but makes you feel like you're in space. The sound FX are also quite decent for the most part, nothing too bad.The gameplay... It's just bad. You can feel like there's a good game deep inside this beast somewhere, but it just can't find it's way out. An attempt to make the game controller-friendly has needlessly obfuscated the interface. Many critical and commonly used functions are buried deep in menus, and you often find that you have to go here or there within the game world just to issue a simplistic command. The "cockpit" that was so painstakingly crafted serves to do little more than just eat up system resources and obscure the screen -- it's not even a HUD integration, it's just a needless visual distraction and resource hog. Whether you use mouse or keyboard, the interface is bad -- just bad. You want some great advice that you'd regret not following? Do not even consider buying this game. Don't look at it, don't watch videos of it, don't make any attempt to think that any amount of patching could fix this mess. It's a broken, clunky, frustrating mess of a game, but it commits the sin of looking like something decent to the uninformed. Consider yourself informed -- don't buy it. DO NOT BUY IT.

content:
Posted: February 16, 2015
												When Egosoft's X3 first came out, I learned first-hand that it installed Starforce malware, so I complained on the Egosoft forums.  They were offended by my complaints and gave me a warning, so I swore off any future Egosoft purchases.  X Rebirth made me change my mind.  (Plus there's no Starforce this time!!!)When Rebirth first came out I did a lot of research and learned that it was a big mess.  So I waited for over a year, did more research, and found that it was faring much better.  This got me to finally buy it during a Steam sale.  Man I'm glad I did!I'm a big sci-fi fan.  I played Freelancer in the past, and am currently playing Starpoint Gemini 2 and Elite Dangerous off and on.X Rebirth is one of the best single-player space experiences I've ever had.  I can see what Egosoft was trying to do with this game, and I think it shines.  Are all the negative reviews warranted?  Early on I'd say absolutely.  But they've patched it up and added to it quite a bit since then.  In my 106 hours of playing I've only had one glitch, and that was getting stuck during docking.  I simply undocked and redocked to fix it.I played the campaign up until the point that I came back to Albion from DeVries and was hostile to everyone.  It was then that I restarted in free mode and have never looked back.  I've upgraded my Skunk to the MK5 shields, the MK3 weapon, and only have 2 more pieces until I have my MK5 engine.  I have the Skunk and 1 Fedhelm freighter, so the plan now is to learn capturing to expand my fleet.  I'd also like to dabble in station building.  There's so much more to do.I've spent a lot of time just travelling around mapping my way and doing missions.  Sightseeing in this game is visually rewarding.  I've gotten used to the flight physics and combat and can hold my own very well.  I've been playing vanilla with no mods the whole time.  I tried changing my cockpit at one point, but none of the others appealed to me.  I've grown used to the clunky large one that came with the Skunk.  I also have no issues with just the one ship.  If I want to get somewhere quick I can dock with my freighter and jump away.Could it be better, sure.  But I think what I've gotten so far for my dollar has paid off in spades.PROS- Visually stunning.- It's as immersive as you allow it to be.- Keyboard/mouse controls are very easy to master and fluid.- Has a decent campaign from what I've played, although I preferred sandbox mode instead.CONS- NPC skins can be horrendous.- Station skins are too repetetive.- Repeating conversations are irksome.- Inability to drop freigher inventory is just plain silly.- Ren and Yisha.  Being able to choose other characters or customize would have been great.Thanks Egosoft!
