content:
Posted: January 31, 2014
												This will be my first review of a game on steam, actually, first review ever. English isn’t my first language, so I will apologize in advanced about any grammar and spelling mistakes.My opinion about this game varies from day to day and from event to event. I will try to make this review as consistent as possible. I’ve been thinking of doing  this review for a long time now. I kept putting it off because I find it very difficult to get my opinion on paper.For those who think this review is too long to read, I’ve put a list of pros and cons at the bottom of this review. The current version of this game is 1.22. a lot of bugs and issues have been addressed by Egosoft at this time. I won’t be writing about earlier issues in this review. There will be issues of course that I haven’t encountered or don’t find annoying or broken. These will not be mentioned either.As you all might know by now, the game is riddled with “major” bugs and flaws. Many of them are annoying, but to say the break the game? I think not. I will try to explain why I think that is. To do this as correctly as possible I’ve divided everything in three categories, bugs, flaws and  wants. But before I do this, I want to stress the fact that Egosoft has been working hard to solve the issues the community has pointed out to them.Bugs:-	Capital ships sometimes fly through stations, this bug isn’t game breaking at all, but it does kill the emersion quite a lot. I’ve encountered this bug at a solar energy plant, where the ship kept flying  through most of the solar panels of the station. It then proceeded to crash into an array of smaller ship which catapulted in to space. Which was cool to see.-	The game sometimes slows down for no apparent reason. For me using the alt-tab keys to go back to Windows and then back to the games, solves this issue. Or else restarting the game entirely.-	Enemies getting stuck inside the station building. Sometimes, enemy drones / fighters fly into or spawn in a solid block of a station. They are then impervious to attack and they don’t go despawn. Missions can’t be completed then because not all enemies are destroyed. When you abort said mission and accept a new one in the same zone, the enemy inside the station gets activated again and you can’t finish the new mission either.Flaws:-	Enemy NPC’s and the police patrols act as they have been trained by monkeys and not very bright ones at that. AI combat and manoeuvring in space should be improved greatly. This will affect the emersion a player can have with the game. -	The game economy is based on trade ships, the trade ships however don’t leave the station. They just fly around it in circles. There are however capital ships that jump between stations and systems to trade.-	Using the jumpdrive of a capital ship should be made easier and more clearer. Look at EVE online for a good way to jump capital ships.Wants:-	Either redo the entire station walking  side of the game or make it so the player doesn’t have to get out of the ship anymore. Trade and talk to people remotely. This however means there has to be a way to make more money in space. Since when you avoid going on to stations you can’t rob said station of its goodies.-	Better galaxy, system, zone, etc. maps. Navigating through these is a pain which, when resolved improves the gameplay drastically.-	Third person view in space! I really want to see what my ship looks like when flying around and blasting stuff.-	Modular ship design of the player ship. It should be possible to remake the ship into a fighter / trader / miner or something else. Now you can only get upgrades, but you aren’t able to trade with energy cells or other materials. You need specialized remote controlled ships for that. For example I should be able to make my ship be able to mine asteroids, but the trade-off should be that my ship is slower and not as well armed. This will al so eliminate the need to crawl around mostly empty stations and robbing them.-	Bring back automated commands on the other player owned ships! Building an empire should be about delegating and getting other people to work for you. Not ordering around brainless monkeys!Stations: Stations are constructed out of modular blocks, which is logical. They have been put together into massive city like  structures which you can fly through / scan  and destroy with your ship. So far so good. On the outside the station look great and they really give off the immense scale of the game.On the inside however they are very underpopulated and at the same time feel very cramped and small. The immenseness is completely lost.AI: The general AI used by the NPC pilots is poor at best. Capital ships tend to fly through stations and bump traffic circling said station. Pirates attacking stations actually bump against it and sit on its outer hull. Fighters / drones defending a target only react when tacking direct fire.Emersion:I find the emersion to be great when flying the ship in space, but completely lost when existing the said and entering the station. Docking in capital ships and such is a great feature. But the walking around needs a lot of work. I am betting the community is making mods as we speak to greatly improve or disable this feature completely. If not, Egosoft should be doing something about this.The space environments are wonderfully made and really get you in a sci-fi mood.Pros:-	Awesome space vista’s, the stations look great, despite the fact they are modular and the asteroid field and the backgrounds simply look great!-	Flying the “Albion Skunk” (the player ship) is as smooth as a baby’s bottom. Especially when the engines have been upgraded a bit.-	Great emersion when flying around in space. Exploring the stations and the asteroid fields in all their details is quite captivating.-	Being an X game, it’s quite challenging, a lot of stuff to figure out. This can be fun, but all so frustrating at times.-	There seems enough to do in the game so people won’t get bored easily. It takes a lot of time to figure out how everything works, but that is a reward in itself, at least for me It is.Cons: -	In station walking is a failure. All the stations are exactly the same on the inside, including the rubbish people leave around. Stations are only populated by 10 – 15 people, which is strange since they are as huge as cities! Rooms and bars are empty and I as a player lose my emersion when walking in a station. Furthermore not many items can be interacted with. When a station is damaged, the internal damage seems massive and the people in it simply don’t care!-	In early game, you will spend a lot of time crawling through stations in search for loot. More simply put, you need to rob the stations blind to get enough stuff to sell back to the few people who live in those stations. Ships that you can buy to start building, shooting, trading or mining your way across the universe are too expensive to get with just simple mission running or doing other stuff in space.-	The voice acting of NPC’s is terrible, they only have a few lines they keep repeating over and over. (I only tested the English voices.)-	The textures for people -	 Bugs, the game doesn’t run as good as it could be, some people still have performance issues and the game does have some odd behaviour now and again. Conclusion:Reading back on this review I can see that it has been somewhat negative and there is indeed much room left in the game for improvement. But the feeling of flying around in that ship and skimming the surface of stations, asteroids and capital ships alike, is just too damn great. So I will recommend this game. When Egosoft (maybe with the help of the community) fix most of the bugs and the whole station walking debacle, they will have made space simulator gold.

content:
Posted: August 5, 2016
												(Don't sweat the time on record - I have the no-Steam .exe)I must have come to X: Rebirth at just the right time, because for the life of me I can't understand the issues previous posters had (except the ones who are die-hard X Series fans who were expecting more of the same - this ain't your grandaddy's X!)PROS:* Huge sandboxy universe* Everything's much much much MUCH prettier than in any previous X installment* New DLC added more to explore* Same robust modding community the game has always enjoyed* YOU CAN GET OUT OF YOUR DAMNED SHIP NOW WHEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEE* Interface requires a certain intelligence level to properly and fully use (yes, I count this as a perk)CONS:* Capital ships are not directly controllable in this installment* Someone airbrushed a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ furry on my ride (bet I can mod it off though)* Bring the latest CPU AND GPU - you're gonna need bothI've been a fan of Egosoft's space entries since X2. So, I guess I know ahead of time to wait about a year or two after the game is released to actually buy in. I decided to take the same wait-to-buy approach with this game, and I feel it's paid off after reading previous reviews from individuals who either didn't know this or knew this but for some odd reason thought things would be different this time around.I got a game that's freakin' huge in scope (even with a jump drive installed - and yes, you can have a jump drive on the Skunk despite what lesser-informed individuals might have to say on the subject; if you don't believe me you can look it up for yourself), but is a manageable challenge. Whereas other games like Elite Dangerous and No Man's Sky just throw up an impossible amount of procedurally-generated cookie-cutter content and call it gameplay, X: Rebirth does a much better job of the three of making its universe seem ALIVE. There is still no better economic simulator in the space sim genre. Another key factor that sets this game apart from its newer challengers is the modding community. Go on. Try modding either one of those two games. See how fast you lose access to the game you purchased. But with X:R? Fuggetaboutit. Mod this thing six ways to Sunday if you like. If it's good enough, your mod may very well make it into the game. It's happened before.Control scheme is highly customizable, at least for space sim fans. X Series has never been an entry-level game and I'm glad Egosoft didn't dumb it down like so many games (SWTOR, WoW, pretty much any MMO really) are doing to make their product appeal to stupid people. Dummies need not apply.I was a little bummed that capital ships can't be directly controlled anymore, since my favored ride in X3TC was a Kyoto. But then I installed the Capital Ship Bridge (4.0+) mod, and lemme tell ya - it's hard to keep myself from thinking I'm not on the bridge of a Galaxy-class starship exploring strange new worlds. I would prefer the option to directly control my superboat in the sequel... because I will definitely be purchasing the sequel....after waiting for the launch bugs to be smoothed, of course. ;-)

Posted: February 22
												The best example i got under my hand to describe X rebirth is that feature i found after 15hours of playtime. There was a little arrow around my reticle telling me in which direction my target is but it was so tiny i didn't see it until then. And that's what X Rebirth is about, everything is there but it's either badly explained, not explained or confusing. It's so unfortunate because the gameplay is particularly rich. The patience & investment one is willing to accept to enjoy a game differs and that might be a reason why this game is so negatively viewed (added to a terrible launch in 2013, and a take down for X3 fans that waited for a modern X3).That said, the rest has been a blast. The universe is huge and fun to visit, either it's about discovering new stations to enhance your choice of action in trading or fighting, flying in an asteroid field looking for glorious profitsss or tracking an isolated massive transport ship to board, there are tons of things to do. Each part of the gameplay is a game in the game and traditionally, egosoft like the player to set his own goals and mine has been to develop an empire, flying around with trusted wingman and some capital ships, deploying a trade company made of stations & trade fleet.Again, you're warned, X rebirth won't hold your hand and requires a wikipedia or a research in the steam forum from time to time. It's not your classic X3 experience where you start in a fighter and end with a carrier with 50 of those docked in. But honestly, Egosoft devs knows what they are doing when it's about to make you feel in space. Recommended

content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												this game gets a lot of bad reviews, and i dont think it entirely deserves it. REVIEW 1-- (for fans of the series, and veteran X players)if it is taken entirely within the confines of the X series (up to this point), it is certainly a rebirth for the series, and it is also a throwback to the first (remember that one, folks? we could only fly one ship there too...). now that version 3.0 has been released, much of the functionality of the previous titles in this series has been restored. taken within the boundries of the X series alone, i would rate this one 8/10 at this point in time. REVIEW 2-- (for new players lured into the series by this title)taken out of the context of its predecessors, however, it is a different story all together. this game has a cumbersome menu system that takes quite some time to get used to, as the assignments some functions are given often make little sense (for instance, changing budgets for station managers took a look up on google for me to figure out) so it loses points there, the graphics are a cross between "woah! thats awesome!" and "WTF is that? a person?" so it loses points for that as well. building an empire takes a lot of time, so its not for casual players. this is the kind of game that you need to get in to, and really it doesnt have much of a problem achieving that sort of immersion if you are playing the story (even if you arent familiar with the previous titles in the series, you can be drawn into the high stakes world of multi galaxy war easily). its easy for me to care what races win the war, and what races are exterminated in the process. but the fact remains that if you intend to play this game and enjoy it, you must also intend to spend 20-40 hours learning the game systems as well. for a lot of people, this will drop the score. for me, this increases it. the more complex the systems are, the more freedom we are generally given to play our way. and in this series, and this game in particular, playing our way is the key. the music seems deliberately strange (it always has in x games though). traveling around in space is also quite boring at times. if you want to know why, read the hitchhikers guide to the galaxy's entry on the size of space to understand why. the number of mods available on the workshop to enhance the game is gaining momentum as new fans are brought in to the series by this title, and often egosoft turns to the modding community when deciding what dlc or patches should be applied to their product so they not only listen to community input, occasionally they use it directly. but new players to the series need to remember one thing- you are playing a sim of sorts. this is not intended to be all action all the time. there are lags of hours and hours spend making the credits you need to continue, and it can be a little tedious. and frustrating when that ship you just spent the day making money to buy gets destroyed cause it had no excorts protecting it. but, this game is also easy as pie to cheat at so... taken out of its own context, i would rate it 6/10. hope you found this review helpful!

content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												Whatever you find attractive in this game with the exception of the empire / industry building, find something that can do it better. Won't be hard, but finding something that does it great and looks great too (equal or better) if you are into "oh I want to get into the space sim genre and this game might be good for me", DO NOT BUY THIS.It is broken from the first to the last feature. The AI is completely dead, which is unforgivible and utterly destroys the whole pure sandbox economy world. Ships are running into each other, local forces are made to be weird (anyone shooting at you is fine, if you shoot back 6 cops are shooting you to death without question). The story is unplayable since 2.0 since the main concept is that you have one ship and you cannot fly another at all. So it was the "superhero never dies" kind of ship, until it was nerfed back to "just one from others" level. Good luck doing story stuff that was designed for the original and puts you up against 6-10 other hunter ships. Attacking other people you were supposed to help, so they can just stand there and watch you die while nobody shoots at them the moment you show up.The controls are terrible. They DESPERATELY wanted to make it work with a controller. Imagine using an Excel table with controller. 5-6 circle menus and submenus in a row to find ANYTHING. Illogical, uncomfortable, weirdly working features accessible from even worse menus. And on top of all this, it is the most poorly optimalized game of the recent years more broken than AC: Unity was at relase. No joke.Whatever you want from this genre, whatever you look for in space sim games, get Elite: Dangerous instead. Or anything else but this. It took the devs several YEARS of patching to make X3 titles good. May be worked back then, but the genre   is starting to live it's second golden age and there are PLENTY of other titles to choose from. No matter what is your goal with them, I can guarantee NOTHING of them can be fulfilled with X: Rebirth. It takes a few hours of playing to understand why and how disfunctional and hopelessly broken it is, so belive me (and countless negative reviews) when I say you better throw that money out of the window than spending on this.

												I read many reviews of this game before purchasing, and found many of the items were correct in the early stages of release.  However at current state this is a game I am having difficulty putting it down.  The stations are huge and it is possible to play this game 120+ hours and never even see half of the content becuase there is just so much out there. Being as I started in the X series with X3 shortly before rebirth came out and have 500 plus hours of gametime in terran conflict and Albion Prelude the best thing I can say about rebirth is that you don't start off as cannon fodder any time you are in a fight. content:
Posted: May 21, 2014
												bugs, bugs, bugs, bugs, bugs, bugs and oh...did I mention bugs?  I had a lot of excitement for X Rebirth.  The idea that I could walk on stations, and on the bridge of my own ship, was very enticing.  Unfortunately, the reality was a far cry different than any other "X" game out there.  While you CAN walk around on stations, and inside of your own ship, a lot of the interactions were buggy and time consuming.  Even worse, you are pretty much STUCK on your ship that you begin the game with.  While you can buy additional ships, and hire people to crew them, you cannot pilot them yourself, which is probably one of the main things that ruined the overall experience that has traditionally been a part of "X" games for years.Also, the control scheme has, if it is even possible, become even more convoluted.  While some things were improved upon, such as the ability to order your traders to buy or sell (A nice little menu, once you get used to it), the overall way you interact with stations has been dumbed down to become "XBox Controller friendly".  I understand WHY they did this, but it didn't quite work.  It just didn't FEEL right.The voice acting is horrible.  In a game like this, it usually isn't that important, but where EVERYTHING is voice acted, I quickly found myself wishing I could turn off the voiceovers - especially where my so-called co-pilot is concerned.  It went from charming to annoying very quickly.Over the last year, they've done a lot to patch the game, which is commendable.  The game was simply not playable when it first came out.  In fact, I suspect the game should have been considered early access, not retail release.  It made me wonder if they have a QA department at ALL.  If they did, they should fire their whole department, because they obviously did not do their jobs.  In my opinion, the game could not be considered "retail" until the last couple of patches.In summation, if you are a fan of the "X" games, I would suggest that you may wish to stay with Albion Prelude and hope that either egosoft scraps this new direction and returns to its roots, or looks at some of the emerging (and perhaps more promising) development efforts under way at various studios, such as Limit Theory.

content:
Posted: August 13, 2014
												A fantastic "Space Trader" game.I preface this by saying that I never played the other X games, don't often like straight up flight sims, and usually play with a controller. This review is coming from that perspective.After reading the reviews of this game, I was convinced I waould hate it. Even after the 2.0 patch, I remained uncertain. I'm glad I took the plunge.Go into this game expecting a classic "Space Trader" game and you will be blown away. Even with the remaining bugs, lack of variety in ground maps, lack of any real ship interiors, and a steep advancement curve, I have quickly fallen for Rebirth.It's essentially the ultimate space ship sandbox game. You have a ship and some cash, go play. The standard "merc, trader, pirate" options are there. However, due to the MASSIVE scale of this game's physical universe and socioeconomic simulations they feel more like "Han Solo, The Emperor, and the head of the Orion Syndicate." You literally go from running small amounts of cargo between stations in your one little ship to operating a massive empire of ships and stations that spans a space so large it can take hours (of real time) to traverse... from your one little ship. This also makes projects immensely satisfying when they eventually finish. You go from "crap, how am I ever gonna get enough cash for this station?" to "Damn, there are a ton of supplies involved in building a station and it's gonna take forever!" to "Cool! Those cargo drones are actually building my station!" to "Wait... this wasn't here befo... oh wait, it's green, this is MY station!"It is a slow and methodical game (unless you just want to shoot things then you go do that while the game slowly and methoically reacts to what you're doing and changes the unverse in response) but a very rewarding one.Now, don't get me wrong, many of the gripes people have with this game are valid:Ground maps are very repetitive, you only get to fly one ship and it really only has one room (technically two but one is just a waiting room/hangar bay that you spend very little time in), the dialogue is fairly generic and repetitive, and there's a lot of waiting around or traversing huge distances.But, as of 2.0 it's thouroughly enjoyable if you know what you're getting in to and worth buying, ESPECIALLY if they do another (hopefully better timed and received) sale.Everything I've read about this company and this game leads me to beleive that there will be a 3.0 and it will probably be free, there's no damn microtransactions, it's not an MMO, and it's not procedural (don't get me wrong, procedural worlds are awesome, but a hand crafted universe of this scale is rare and usually amazing) so this truly is a unique and incredible game in the current industry. Some people will genuinely hate Rebirth with good reason but, knowing what I was getting into, I have found it to quickly become my favorite Space Trader in a very very long time. So my advice is this: if you think you might still want this game even after reading about the downsides... yes, you REALLY do!

												X:Rebirth ReviewBefore we get started know that I have played all the X3 games and that you should forget all the reviews you have heard unless they were made in August 2014+ because this is a whole new game!Pros:HUGE Universe +A TON of AI ships that you can talk to +A lot of stations+Amazing Graphics+Great Controls (For keyboard and mouse)+A wide variety of modes (Freeplay, Campaign or different scenerios)+VERY Complex+Play your way type of game+Not too hard (if you play on Normal or Easy)+Open World+Shows the cockpit unlike X3 Games. +You can play this for HOURS +The menu/ pressing enter is very simple +Neutrals:It does REGONIZE the joysticks and gamepads but we will get to that soon =Voice Acting is robotic but it will do =Not TOO hard but is kinda hard to learn at first =The sun in game hurts my eyes it is so bright =Cons:The sound in the station sounds AWFUL it is a low ringing noise -Controls are not optimized for joysticks -Hard to keybind -This game had the second worst launch in game history (Behind AC:Unity) -Not enough (Empire building) I wish you could create factions -All in all this is one of the best space games now! 8/10

												XRebirth 4.0: The patches have fixed all the game breaking bugs, the expansions have added a lot of content, and there are many mods to help improve the game as well and I'd highly suggest looking at some of the most subscribed ones.Overall Egosoft stuck with it and it's paid off.  For all the people that cry you can only play in one ship, I think 80% of them would still stick with that ship if given the choice simply because it has the best stats & they'd be calling people fools for using anything else while patting themselves on the back for their minmaxing prowess.  Just like they did with the other X-games.The pros are this game lets you do just about anything you want, amass a fleet of trading, mining, and combat ships.  Build up an empire of space stations to corner the market on goods.The biggest negative for me is the user interface, imagine trying to run an empire from your car with just an old style flip phone.  If they would give us more of a galactic scale view ala civilization or even a starcraft level view to control ships & stations it would help out a lot once you hit a point where you have many ships/stations all over the star systems.I would recommend buying this if you love these kinds of games like Privateer, or Freelancer.  But this is definitely a worthwhile buy during the Steam sales where the price gets cut down to 50%-75% off.

												Really wished this was a remaster of X3:Albion Prelude. Instead we get a game that seemed to try to get into the console space (there are place holder files for XBOX 360). Everything failed because of thier design choice - they wanted to make interiors of ships and stations which would be a huge undertaking. This is one of the reasons why you can only pilot one ship. This is like windows 8 situation. Developers try to change up too many things that they feel works better but goes against the design flow of previous iterations. This results in failure. Don't buy. Wait for X4, hopefully Egosoft learn thier mistake. I still bought this to support them since I got like 2000+ hours of fun from X3 (if X4 is terrible I will be done with Egosoft).

content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												Aside from what I wrote when this game came out.  This is the ONE game that soured every game I purchase now.  I am EXTREMELY careful about what I buy.  I wait until I see the reviews.  I look at the broadcasts.  I check metacritic.  This game was the worst piece of crap I have ever purchased at 50.00+  and steam would not give me a refund on this.  About the only other game I regret buying was minerwars 2033 at 25 dollars in alpha mode when they promised an MMO.  This game is absolute and utter garbage.------------------Please don't even consider this game or otherwise pile of crap.   The numerous bugs will not let you continue, the graphics are recycled in every spacestation with absolutely no change between stations.  The controls are not intuitive.. absolute crap.  The worst part about it is the $50.00 they are charging for this.  Highway robbery.  The developers knew what they were throwing out there and unfortunately many people took the bait.  If you really want to know more about this game, read on:1) From the very begining you are completely lost.  You will not be able to figure out what controls do what.  People have taken 30 minutes just to figure out that a very small little button is used to dock.  This button might not even pop up unless you are a certain distance from where you need to be and in a precise location.  On top of that, there is a bug which sometimes even prevents this little icon from coming up!  I thought I was a complete idiot for not finding this thing.. until I restarted the game and reloaded a save, the icon to dock came up.2) Every spacestation you go to looks EXACTLY the same.  The developers want you to go in the "Air Ducts" to find random money (who leaves money in the ducts?).  It really is frustrating for someone to go in the space station, look for a duct and try to find a pitance for all that work.3) The trading system is absolutely horrendous. In the real world you go to Walmart (or you find an advertised price) and you can go, Mmm lets say ebay and see that people are buying a certain item for more.  So you go to walmart, but the item cheaper and resell it at ebay for a profit.  Done deal.  In the game, you buy an item and you thinl "ok.. I am going to sell this item for more.."  but then you look and look and you look.  It will take you at the very least 5-6 hours just to find any other place that sells or buys that same item!!! on top of that you can't even figure out the price of it.  Even if you do sell the items, you will make a very small amount of money to not even make it worth your time.4)  When you go to a vendor.. they all look the same, they all say the same thing.  For a game that was in development for 7 years you would think they would at least have different vendors say different things or something a bit more interesting.  You have one of 3 different stories you can hear from them.  "Show me your warez"!  5) When you do take these space highways you have NO idea where you are going.  You just take one and hope for the best.  You have no maps, or anything that gives you a semblance of where here might be.  On top of that, you have to tailgate a ship to go faster??  Wouldn't you be afraid of that if you are traveling close to the speed of light?6) Space in Xrebirth isn't very big.  It feels actually extremely small for what they have.7) There are game breaking bugs that prevent you from continuing further in missions (like the Energy cell mission)8)  When someone is attacking you and you are defending yourself.  You are using a joystick to try to hit the enemy.  The enemy might be in between you and the spacestation.  You gun will now hit the spacestation and now you become the bad guy.  Be prepared for the police to start aiming you.9) did I mention you can hear the police siren?  WTF.  Space is void of air, how the hell does the sound travel?10)  Whenever you want to see the stats of an NPC you are hiring.. you click on a menu item to allow the NPC to show you their qualifications before you hire them.  That is broken as well.  You see nothing there (only stars)11) You can steal items from your own ships and resell them (how does that work?  you find stuff in crates in your own ships and resell them)I don't know.. I can keep going on and on and on.  I would've been more descriptive had I known that steam was going to be launching this whole steam review.  This game is very poorly made and the developers knew what they were throwing out there.  It is extremely sad they charged 50 dollars for this.  This game has just ruined it for all pre-orders on steam since I will never ever purchase another game on pre-order even at a discounted price without seeing what people are saying about the game.

content:
Posted: April 15, 2015
												This is the best space sim/space opera I've ever played.This game got a bad wrap due to early bugs which have now (for the most part) been fixed. The team at Egosoft regularly release patches so most of the negative reviews are now null and void.You basically build stations (eventually creating your own 'empire'), amass a fleet, trade, steal ships, blow up enemies, protect friends. All the stuff a space opera should have. If you've played Eve, this is very similar, except you are stuck with the one ship the whole game. There's a ever changing economy to get involved in and plenty more to keep you busy for 100's of hours (I've racked up 426 hrs since i bought the game about a month and a bit ago).Ignore the negative reviews, the are outdated and don't carry a lot of weight anymore. That being said, there are still some glitches, most of which can be solved by changing zones, others by reading some of the forums, the rest with mods (and the modding community has got some really talented people behind it).

content:
Posted: January 20, 2015
												When X Rebirth was first released I along with many others were very disappointed in what I saw.Then I thought to myself, Hang on, This is Egosoft here, they NEVER abandon their games, maybe this can be fixed..So I settled in for the wait, read all the negative reviews, watched soo many you tube videos of people slamming rebirth, thinking all along, I know they going to fix it..Sure, I admit, egosoft stuffed up badly (more than they ever have in the past) but I had faith (and no I am not a fanboy, I just love the X series (I been playing them for over 12 years))I started playing properly once Egosoft opened up the beta program to all (which I joined in on), now we are at v3.10 and I thought it was time to say something..X Rebirth has come a long way since it was released, now I can honestly say that it is well worth playing.They have changed a lot of things the players wanted changed, they have actually listened to the players, and have even taken the unheard of step in actually talking and listening to players on their forums (which before rebirth this was almost unheard of)There are still things that need fixing, but the modding community is getting behind Egosoft and are making mods that pick up things which Egosoft have not put into the game (yet?)There is a current up to date list of mods here - http://forum.egosoft.com/viewtopic.php?t=370788 if anyone wishes to have a look.All in all, my rating for x rebirth AT RELEASE would have been a 3/10 - NOW I would give it a 8/10.With all the mods that are being released things keep getting better... - Give it a go, you may be in for a suprise...

content:
Posted: November 19, 2014
												First let me say this, when i first bought this game, it was a mess. I really cluster****. But since Nov2013, there have been a series of huge patches. At first they were very weak attempts to corrects the glaring amount of bugs, glitches, and just plan terrible thinking, when egosoft first released this game it was litterally impossible for the normal gamer to get past serious glitches. However, this game is visually stunning. The model work is absolutely fantastic. The detail to everything, except the actual character models, which are abit laughable, even now despite the fact that before there was an irrational number of granny-like humans in the universe, so much so that there was an actual mod to get rid of the grannies. Anyway, despite all the mistakes, the team at egosoft have repeated patched and worked there butts off to make this game a complete work.  Too many times have a seen a game with promise killed because the work needed to finish it was not done. This time, despite the terrible reviews, this team has continued to work on a game that people have called it quits on. I honest feel better about supporting a developer who is willing to keep working on a game even though everyone else said it was over. And in the end they have honestly and truely turned this game around. I have almost 400 hours of gameplay so i can speak about this with some degree of experience, this game is definitely worth a look. If you like space sims, 4x, RPGRTS, wait for it to go on sale if you are poor, or just nab it up. I dont write reviews normally, but I feel that with as much work as this crew has put into correcting their mistakes, they are honest and they truely want to put out a good game. And this was pretty long-winded, but i felt they havent been treated fairly since they have been successfully fixing their mistakes.

												Aside from what I wrote when this game came out.  This is the ONE game that soured every game I purchase now.  I am EXTREMELY careful about what I buy.  I wait until I see the reviews.  I look at the broadcasts.  I check metacritic.  This game was the worst piece of crap I have ever purchased at 50.00+  and steam would not give me a refund on this.  About the only other game I regret buying was minerwars 2033 at 25 dollars in alpha mode when they promised an MMO.  This game is absolute and utter garbage.------------------Please don't even consider this game or otherwise pile of crap.   The numerous bugs will not let you continue, the graphics are recycled in every spacestation with absolutely no change between stations.  The controls are not intuitive.. absolute crap.  The worst part about it is the $50.00 they are charging for this.  Highway robbery.  The developers knew what they were throwing out there and unfortunately many people took the bait.  If you really want to know more about this game, read on:1) From the very begining you are completely lost.  You will not be able to figure out what controls do what.  People have taken 30 minutes just to figure out that a very small little button is used to dock.  This button might not even pop up unless you are a certain distance from where you need to be and in a precise location.  On top of that, there is a bug which sometimes even prevents this little icon from coming up!  I thought I was a complete idiot for not finding this thing.. until I restarted the game and reloaded a save, the icon to dock came up.2) Every spacestation you go to looks EXACTLY the same.  The developers want you to go in the "Air Ducts" to find random money (who leaves money in the ducts?).  It really is frustrating for someone to go in the space station, look for a duct and try to find a pitance for all that work.3) The trading system is absolutely horrendous. In the real world you go to Walmart (or you find an advertised price) and you can go, Mmm lets say ebay and see that people are buying a certain item for more.  So you go to walmart, but the item cheaper and resell it at ebay for a profit.  Done deal.  In the game, you buy an item and you thinl "ok.. I am going to sell this item for more.."  but then you look and look and you look.  It will take you at the very least 5-6 hours just to find any other place that sells or buys that same item!!! on top of that you can't even figure out the price of it.  Even if you do sell the items, you will make a very small amount of money to not even make it worth your time.4)  When you go to a vendor.. they all look the same, they all say the same thing.  For a game that was in development for 7 years you would think they would at least have different vendors say different things or something a bit more interesting.  You have one of 3 different stories you can hear from them.  "Show me your warez"!  5) When you do take these space highways you have NO idea where you are going.  You just take one and hope for the best.  You have no maps, or anything that gives you a semblance of where here might be.  On top of that, you have to tailgate a ship to go faster??  Wouldn't you be afraid of that if you are traveling close to the speed of light?6) Space in Xrebirth isn't very big.  It feels actually extremely small for what they have.7) There are game breaking bugs that prevent you from continuing further in missions (like the Energy cell mission)8)  When someone is attacking you and you are defending yourself.  You are using a joystick to try to hit the enemy.  The enemy might be in between you and the spacestation.  You gun will now hit the spacestation and now you become the bad guy.  Be prepared for the police to start aiming you.9) did I mention you can hear the police siren?  WTF.  Space is void of air, how the hell does the sound travel?10)  Whenever you want to see the stats of an NPC you are hiring.. you click on a menu item to allow the NPC to show you their qualifications before you hire them.  That is broken as well.  You see nothing there (only stars)11) You can steal items from your own ships and resell them (how does that work?  you find stuff in crates in your own ships and resell them)I don't know.. I can keep going on and on and on.  I would've been more descriptive had I known that steam was going to be launching this whole steam review.  This game is very poorly made and the developers knew what they were throwing out there.  It is extremely sad they charged 50 dollars for this.  This game has just ruined it for all pre-orders on steam since I will never ever purchase another game on pre-order even at a discounted price without seeing what people are saying about the game.

												When X Rebirth was first released I along with many others were very disappointed in what I saw.Then I thought to myself, Hang on, This is Egosoft here, they NEVER abandon their games, maybe this can be fixed..So I settled in for the wait, read all the negative reviews, watched soo many you tube videos of people slamming rebirth, thinking all along, I know they going to fix it..Sure, I admit, egosoft stuffed up badly (more than they ever have in the past) but I had faith (and no I am not a fanboy, I just love the X series (I been playing them for over 12 years))I started playing properly once Egosoft opened up the beta program to all (which I joined in on), now we are at v3.10 and I thought it was time to say something..X Rebirth has come a long way since it was released, now I can honestly say that it is well worth playing.They have changed a lot of things the players wanted changed, they have actually listened to the players, and have even taken the unheard of step in actually talking and listening to players on their forums (which before rebirth this was almost unheard of)There are still things that need fixing, but the modding community is getting behind Egosoft and are making mods that pick up things which Egosoft have not put into the game (yet?)There is a current up to date list of mods here - http://forum.egosoft.com/viewtopic.php?t=370788 if anyone wishes to have a look.All in all, my rating for x rebirth AT RELEASE would have been a 3/10 - NOW I would give it a 8/10.With all the mods that are being released things keep getting better... - Give it a go, you may be in for a suprise...

												First let me say this, when i first bought this game, it was a mess. I really cluster****. But since Nov2013, there have been a series of huge patches. At first they were very weak attempts to corrects the glaring amount of bugs, glitches, and just plan terrible thinking, when egosoft first released this game it was litterally impossible for the normal gamer to get past serious glitches. However, this game is visually stunning. The model work is absolutely fantastic. The detail to everything, except the actual character models, which are abit laughable, even now despite the fact that before there was an irrational number of granny-like humans in the universe, so much so that there was an actual mod to get rid of the grannies. Anyway, despite all the mistakes, the team at egosoft have repeated patched and worked there butts off to make this game a complete work.  Too many times have a seen a game with promise killed because the work needed to finish it was not done. This time, despite the terrible reviews, this team has continued to work on a game that people have called it quits on. I honest feel better about supporting a developer who is willing to keep working on a game even though everyone else said it was over. And in the end they have honestly and truely turned this game around. I have almost 400 hours of gameplay so i can speak about this with some degree of experience, this game is definitely worth a look. If you like space sims, 4x, RPGRTS, wait for it to go on sale if you are poor, or just nab it up. I dont write reviews normally, but I feel that with as much work as this crew has put into correcting their mistakes, they are honest and they truely want to put out a good game. And this was pretty long-winded, but i felt they havent been treated fairly since they have been successfully fixing their mistakes.

Posted: April 15, 2015
												This is the best space sim/space opera I've ever played.This game got a bad wrap due to early bugs which have now (for the most part) been fixed. The team at Egosoft regularly release patches so most of the negative reviews are now null and void.You basically build stations (eventually creating your own 'empire'), amass a fleet, trade, steal ships, blow up enemies, protect friends. All the stuff a space opera should have. If you've played Eve, this is very similar, except you are stuck with the one ship the whole game. There's a ever changing economy to get involved in and plenty more to keep you busy for 100's of hours (I've racked up 426 hrs since i bought the game about a month and a bit ago).Ignore the negative reviews, the are outdated and don't carry a lot of weight anymore. That being said, there are still some glitches, most of which can be solved by changing zones, others by reading some of the forums, the rest with mods (and the modding community has got some really talented people behind it).

content:
Posted: March 20, 2015
												TL;DR---------------------- Don't buy it in a year or however long someone told you it would take for this game to be ready- Don't buy it on discount. No amount of money should be paid for this game.- Dont. Buy. It.---------------------The X games have always been close to my heart. X3 did so many wonderful things for the genre. It improved upon the issues of the previous titles while adding what seemed to be boundless possibilities for customization and replay. X3 was the “be anyone you want” of space sims. Beyond that, the games always had a robust following of experienced and talented modders that provided even more customization and options to make the universe more alive.It was that consistency of greatness that drew my eye to Rebirth. I was captivated by amazing visuals and the promise of an even bigger universe than the previous games. All of this came crashing down, however, on the day of release. Steam comments flooded in claiming the game was nearly unplayable, and that the new features had drastically reduced the diversity of the gameplay. There was hope, however, as Egosoft heard the public’s plea and promised to introduce fixes in the future. Additionally, the modding community could pick up any slack the developers left behind, right? Wrong.It is now more than a year after release and the fundamental issues that make this game such a poor installment in this universe are still going strong. What was once a complex and diverse universe is now nothing more than a light framework for a space sim. The degree of customization and control has been stunted to an awful degree. Control of ships is absurdly confusing and requires you to continuously jaunt through infuriatingly vague menu commands that ultimately lead nowhere. You are confined (piloting-wise) to one ship, which is not as big a deal as it might seem, but the lack of control makes it too much of a hassle to play.Even the mods for the game are surprisingly unimpressive. There is no XRM or CODEA. That’s not to say there aren’t helpful mods out there, but they just don’t add the same degree of life as the mods of the previous X games. If you aren’t a German speaking player, you are also subject to some of the most awful (often to the point of hilarity) voice over work ever presented in a game. It shouldn’t be difficult for Egosoft to find native English, French, or Russian speakers to handle the localization and voice work for the game. The arduously broken English doesn’t just pull you out of the game, it makes you feel like there wasn’t really any effort put into it. It honestly would have been better if there weren’t any speech at all, just text.I feel very badly for those who paid full price for this. The game seems like it was made by children. Some of the “features” seem like something your 12-year-old nephew might suggest. The rest of the game is stale, lifeless, and oversimplified. I get that this isn’t supposed to be “X4,” but does that really justify the release of such an lack-luster product?

Forget it: you´re stuck inside a flinsy little m3 that´s also a marine frigate - FOREVER. In X3 you would fly her a lot to board capitals, but never into battle against large enemy squads. Here, you don´t have a choice: it´s a flimsy M3 forever and take it.  And try to build a station in this game: Egosoft created a whole new level for the word 'imcompetence' when then maded decisions for this crap - essential resources unavailable due to plotline and complete lack of tutorials will make you rage, but not as much as when a 'captain' is limited to only transfer FIVE goods at a time to the construction vessel, pausing for almost 30 minutes to reposition his ship into dumb waiting mode.  X-Rebirth is NOT worth an AAA title price.  It´s a bargain bin game that you may play while waiting for X4.---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Released broken.  They completely ignored the fanbase, trapped the player in a single ship, messed the menu to be "controller" friendly and REMOVED ALL THE CONTROL MENUS THAT MADE X GAMES PLAYABLE. The human models are horrible, and most of the capital ships functionality aren´t intuitive at all - they tried to dumb the game down, but that just broke it. You´ll see that if you play it - the game simple break and stop to a halt in a plotline food delivery mission because only ONE type of capital ship can do it. If you remember how messy was the launch of X3: Reunion, then ask no more - Egosoft did it again. Imagine you playing Terran Conflict WITHOUT being able to control your ships remotely... you get the picture. All it needed for it to NOT to bomb was an "early access" sign... this is NOT the sequel to X3:terran conflict or X3: Albion Prelude. Don´t dissapoint yourself, and wait for X4.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2014
												This is a total waste of money.It has poor interface. It feels like it was planned to be released as a console game but the devs changed their mind at the last minute and converted it to PC only. So now we have a gamepad optimised UI that is very difficult to interact with a mouse and a keyboard, specially because it is incredibly small.It has a cockpit... that is constantly in your way when you try to play the game taking a lot of viewing space (nothing like the clean X3 view) with annoying animations, ♥♥♥♥♥ing Betty constantly ♥♥♥♥♥ing about everything, and the female companion competing against Betty to see who can talk and annoy you more. Also, there are no external views whatsoever.The "walk outside of your ship" every time you dock at a station is pointless, inefficient, frustrating and annoying. Besides it seems like there are only 2 or 3 different “looks” for the hundreds of station and ship docks which, after a while, gets quite boring.The map is utterly confusing and awkward, nothing like the ugly but efficient map of X3.Performance issues. The game feels quite responsive and fluid until you get hit with a performance drop out of the blue.Bug ridden. This game has so many bugs it feels like an alpha. Some of them can break your game progress forcing you to restart from the very beginning. Other bugs are quite frustrating like ships not following commands or factories not building and the like.But finally, what was a deal breaker for me, something I couldn’t get over with no matter how many times I tried to convince myself that this was something trivial, was the fact that you CAN’T use other ships than the fugly and crappy Albion Skunk. What the hell man? I mean, in X3 you could use tons of ships. That was something that made that game great, that’s not possible here. It is also worth commenting that there are far fewer ships through out the universe that in X3 so get used to see the same ships all over the place.There are many other annoying things that add up to the frustration of this game like the “highways”, the limited selection on weapons, multiple docking ports on the same station that you have to visit to access the wares or the people there, having to fly around stations to find the right dock, and much more that is not worth commenting anymore.Good things that I really like about this game are the graphics (just gorgeous), the music (quite nice and relaxing) and that there may be some tinny, little, microscopic potential in this game IF (AND ONLY IF) the devs get their act together and fix all the bugs, PLUS if the modding community feel sorry enough about this excuse of a game to try and fix it. Otherwise, I don’t see any future for this crap.So, all in all, this game is a perfectly done turd. If you want to waste $50 bucks go for it. In fact, burning those $50 bucks right now seems like a better idea than buying this game.You have been warned.

content:
Posted: September 11, 2014
												TL/DR - avoid and get X:TC insteadAll I can really say is that its a bit...meh - compared to the previous x-games this one is very very shallow.Its a lot more accessible, I have several large ships and three stations - something that I never would've been able to achieve in the time frame in X:TC, but once you're at this point theres not much for you to actually do.You're locked into a small the entire game, and although there are several upgrades you can get they don't have a hugely substantial effect on your power level.You can dock onto a cap ship but you cant take direct control, you have to give orders to the AI crew - even with max skill stars they are still pants on head ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, and the control interface is absolutely horendous - its practically impossible to tell a knackered ship to retreat from a fight because you need to hail the ship, tell it to stop its current task, then give it a new order IF it hasn't already given itself a new order to attack the thing thats about to kill it - meaning you need to order it to cancel and try to give it a new order again.Another terrible thing is that the game focuses on the idea of 'one man and his ship' to the extreme that you literally have to do everything yourself.1. Want to know whats in a sector and know what trades are on offer? Well say bye to scout ships with scout software with orders to scout the universe going on their merry way; you're going to have to fly to every sector yourself, fly to every station yourself, and if you want those trade offers to stay upto date you're going to have to dock at the station yourself, loiter around yourself until some NPC ♥♥♥♥♥es about something so you can access an incredibly dull talking minigame (of which only half a dozen different convos exist) - thankfully there is a mod to bypass the minigame, but you're still going to have to fly up to every single station.2. Want an NPC mission for dosh? Well dont bother looking for a BBS system - you need to fly around each station until you can find a mission icon.3. Want to use your trader or mining ships to trade or mine without having to attach them to a station? Well you're going to have to do it yourself because there isn't a free trader extension built it (there is a couple of mods to do it however)If you do still want to buy the game, use one of the free starts as the campaign is rubbish with a lackluster ending that renders the home system even more hostile than the xenon one you find.

												i would love to say this is amazing, this is the game i've been telling all of my friends and family i've been waiting for since 2011 after all, but i honestly feel this is the worst x game i've played. egosoft states they have been working on this game for 7 years but with all the bugs, glitches, and fps drops, it kind of feels like they worked on it 7 years ago and just started again a couple of months ago. there are a LOT of changes i was looking forward to and i still feel they could learn from this game and make the future games even better. i like the concept of being able to use the highways to be able to explore more of a particular planet or system and being able to see the consoles in the cockpit of my ship, but to go from the massive galaxy in the previous versions to the tiny map you get now is hard to accept, between that and going from being able to setup and fire all of your weapon systems at once to only being able to use one at a time and a soft target system that never changes the target when i need it to (this in particular has gotten me killed multiple times), not to mention the lack of gravidar and the icons representing ships on your hud hiding behind the panels and struts of the cockpit. it feels like the series is taking a massive swan dive backwards. i LOVE being able to see and attack individual subsystems but between the target assistance (which seems to miss more than i do manually) and the soft targeting it doesn't usually wind up coming into play. i do like being able to hire your crew members and actually putting a face to the people that you leave behind when you lose a ship and the concept of being able to walk around stations while i was really looking forward to it has grown annoying to me now. i like having it as an option but i long for the days of being able to dock at a ship and do everything through the menu's, instead of ponderously waddling around looking for the person you need which may or may not actually have the item you want to buy. you can get discounts by scanning parts of stations or by doing a conversation mini game which i also enjoyed at the start but now after going through the same station layouts seeing the same faces and hearing the same voices over and over again, its gotten rather tiresome. AND WHAT DID THEY DO TO THE SPLIT? i really miss the old split voice and look, they were my favorite species in the previous games. tldr if you like the previous x games buy at your own risk of soul crushing depression.

content:
Posted: March 17, 2015
												I have really poor english, I know. Tl;dr: buy this game only if you really want it and you want to provide developers' your feedback. At this time it's rather unfinished and badly designed.Well. Two hours might not be enough to write a decent review but I don't care much.This game is, well, strange. It's a great 2008 space game, with its bugs, its huge pretentiousness and its very badly modelled story. But this is not an X game and I think it won't ever be until EGOSOFT developers will change their mind on a lot of design decisions. Let's start with a deeper review.First thing I can notice is that the game is really really heavy hardware wise. That's kinda acceptable, it's the trend these days. What isn't acceptable is the huge lack of optimization: 1) Even on minimum graphic settings (no antialias, no shadings, 1280x720, very low textures detail) the game doesn't have solid fps, ranging from 20 to 50fps (most of the times it varies. 40-50 fps facing a wall, 38-45 while moving on a station, 20-30 while in outerspace with ships on screen) on medium end hardware. Most animations also doesn't really exist: in past games if a ship jumped away using a JD you would notice a warp animation and the ship's computer voice telling that it was gone. In rebirth you have no animation for JD and no computer voice. The ship simply despawns. This can be noticed in the second mission, where you take your new aquired female member to a corporation's ship. While flying really close to that ship you can notice that it simply despawns.2) Ships' AI is very badly implemented if you compare it with older x games (taking away that weird bug present in all games from X2 to X3:AP where sometimes a cpu ship would endlessly bump on a station stuck on its way). Most of them will eventually bump on a station or another ship.3) Stations' interiors are full of bugs. I landed on three different stations (and in multiple points of those stations) and 80% of the time I found bugged moments where you could just fall in the void and then respawn in your ship. In the submission where you hire a captain for your capital freighter you land in a sort of night club. After landing you go through a blast door and you find a robot "minding his business". If you bump that robot you'll eventually be thrown away from the station in the 3d void and then respawn. Same thing with the air conductures in that same corridor.4) A lot of ships' 3d models are unstable. In example, while adding a captain to my capital I noticed another capital surrounded by Triath Vanguard fighters. While I was near those fighters I noticed that the left half of those ships was trembling.Design wise this game has an awful lot of bad decisions and bad implementations of good decisions:1) We were advertised that EVERYTHING in the game could influence economical, social and political situations or even the smallest situation in the game. THAT'S FRIGGIN' AWESOME.Well, it would be if it was implemented better. In example: while flying in rebirth I noticed a capital ship blocking an highway. The strange thing is that nothing happened. I flew in the highway but that ship across the tunnel didn't even made me or other ships crash. This is not lack of eye candy, it's lack of a realism which should be the trademark of the game. 2) Station exploring would be an awesome eye catch (and maybe somehow useful to what you are doing) but there's a huge lack of life. NPCs stand still (that's kinda acceptable tough, I guess that making them move would be another huge weight for our poor cpus). You can hear them chatting sometimes but most of the dialogues are repetitive and without any caring. OST is minimal, not many ambient noises.3) The inability to fly any ship other than the Albion Skunk is kinda a huge step back.4) The story is told in a really superficial way. Even by paying maximum attention to every dialogue I found myself going to the next waypoint without even understating what's really going on.5) UI is confusing if compared to the masterpieces UI that were in x2 and x3:R: menus are unclear (I did had a lot of trouble while searching for my cargo bay in the menus) and basic cockpit doesn't even show most of the informations (like speed expressed in numbers along with the usual bar). Maps are the most confusing things I ever seen so far.6) The lack of fundamental features is really disapointing: monitors for targets and objects doesn't exist anymore. SETA is surprisingly absent making most of the first flights REALLY boring.7) Voice acting is mostly bad executed (apart from two actors present even in old installments that are really top tier).8) Highways are kinda ok but they could have been better.9) Docking is a huge pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ searching for a docking bay is a long and boring process, many of the stations' points must be uncovered by yourself and most of the times is a huge time wasting.10) Radio communications aren't useful anymore11) NPC talking is really confusing.12) Don't know if it's because I didn't play much but so far I found only one alien, a split in a station. Also his 3d model was kinda fun, a green man with moustaches. Totally different from the splits I'm used to see. I was kinda amused by the presence of easter eggs like the X:BtF arcade. But they're the only things that tie this game to the X universe.I'll update this review as I dig deeper in the game, for the time being I'm considering this game an engine demostrator and nothing more. Hope that next patches will fix most of the problems I described

												DO NOT BUY. This game is a train wreck, even if you looked at it with fresh eyes ignoring all the glaring things it's missing from past games, it's still just a terrible clunky unoptimized game that's bad at the core level and no amount of bugfixing or patches is going to redeem it. A once great space sim series has been gutted and everything that made it unique and fun and interesting has been dumbed down or just removed. All the menus are clunky and simplified, the game is the definition of unintuitive. Where once you could command fleets and build empires and easily issue orders to specific ships or set them up to autonomously run actions, now you do none of that in X rebirth. Fleet commands? What fleet commands?  Any cool ship you see is instantly made uninteresting when you realize the fact you will never ever get to fly it, enjoy being confined to your boring one ship that can't even be customized or upgraded that much, heck it can't even hull cargo. The devs teased that you would be able to walk around capital ships and command them from the deck indirectly. But this was debunked by them weeks before launch, but I mean they were happy to let rumors run their course. You can dock at capital ships sure, but they can't move around while you're on them, and the interior in them is very small and lackluster, no bridge view whatsoever, in fact no view at all because rendering the outside "living" world while on a space station or Capital ship would have just been to much I guess. We can just chalk all that up to unfinished game syndrome.On the note of space stations, they all look the same, enjoy going to the same looking bar over and over again while you search for an npc to trade with that has the one item you need. Trading is awful, in past X Games it was simple, certain stations produced certain products and it was easy to go between them trading. In X rebirth you have to randomly land at a station and blindly talk to NPC's in hopes they have the products you need. It's very time consuming and pointless, the worst possible way they could have handled trading.This isn't a series reborn, it's a series aborted. This game feels like a tech demo for their new engine or worse yet, and I honestly feel this way, this game seems like some kind of weird spin off egosoft was making for nextgen consoles but due to whatever reason they had to abort and release on PC only. The clunky turbo-bad menu systems feel like they were designed to be controlled solely with a gamepad without the aid of a keyboard or mouse, and they can be.By now this rant has gotten kind of long and I could keep going because I haven't even gotten through half of why this game is such a massive disappointment but I don't think anyone's going to even read this far. This has to be the worst game of 2013. If you want a space game go play X3:Terran Conflict/Albion prelude. Egosoft has one of the most loyal community and fanbase that mod and help fix their games over the years, and they are rewarded with this steaming pile of consolized homgeneous crap.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												Expecting Freelancer, instead got Duke Nukem in SpaceIf anyone who dislike Duke Nukem Forever or Aliens Colonial Marine, you can understand the pain I'm having right now with X-Rebirth. I was expecting a AAA experience with a easier learning curve, which is something that's been keeping me from getting into the X series in the past. I walked in with a lot of expectation, Instead I got a half-baked game, with crappy performance issue, ugly textures and low poly character model.I can point you to various game from LAST-GEN has better aesthetic than this game, the Character Models for example. What is this? Does it has less polygon than a teapot? How could it possibly looks so ugly ? And even if you bump all the effects to maximum, it still doens't look very immpersive. The only nice looking things are SPACE, and SHIPS (from a distance.). The overall performance is horrendous as well, I can run Battlefield 4, Crysis 3 and Far Cry 3 with medium heigh settings at 30~40 fps. For this game, I couldn't  get 30 fps whenI put all the settings to lowest level, it's obvious that this game is rushed or poorly optimized.All the above mention is enough to keep me from playing, I'm not someone who judge a game SOLELY by it's graphics, but all these things really breaks the immersion, there's no way I can contiune playing this game with all these issues. Unless you are a die-hard Fan of the X Series, or you don't mind some last gen low-poly character model, bad voice work and all kinds of game breaking bugs, please don't waste your money. There's NO WAY this game worth 50 $ at it's current state.

												For all the improvements they made to this game it still makes me sad. Not being able to change ships to suit my own playstyle is what did it for me. content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												What started with gorgeous, promising trailers of X Rebirth turned into an unfortunate case of developer myopia on release.  It's bad enough to speculate that perhaps their publisher, Deep Silver, strongarmed them into an early release because, come release day, we were given something riddled with enough show-stopping bugs that this is an "Early Access" game without the benefit that title brings as an excuse.It's possible you might have a little fun here, just scoping out the huge the stations and shooting some things down but, before long, your fun will be soured by nasty performance bugs, broken core systems, and a sorely pointless station interiors.  X Rebirth doesn't just need polish; it needs a massive low-level revision.If you've already bought the game, I wouldn't bother waiting for incremental patches on this one - come back around April or March '14 and see then if X Rebirth is worth playing.  Also, be sure to check out the community mods.Until then, I recommend paying no more than $10 for this game, and cross your fingers that the next game in the X series actually remembers what an X game is.  Terran Conflict or Albion Prelude are entirely different games, and remain reasonably worthy purchases.

content:
Posted: April 4, 2015
												I've waited for a 66% discount to buy this game. Version 3.53, more than a year after one of the most catastrophic launches in gaming history.Most of the things people hated about it were design flaws, things that no patch can actually fix. The main problems I have:1- There are 3 different types of shields and engines, ranging from Mk1 to Mk42- There are 4 weapons and a mining laser.3- Enemy fighters can easily destroy you and are a pain to hit properly.4- While piloting a drone, you'll often find your ship under attack5- Voice acting is audible at best and really bad most of the time.6- Hacking missions. You have to pilot a Trojan drone that is slow while enemies hunt down your ship. You either find somewhere in the middle of a station to hide yourself from fire, or you give up.7- Missions where you need a cargo ship to deliver stuff. Funny thing, these ships are SLOOOOOOOOOOOWWWWW. Add squadrons of enemies to the mix and you get yourself a nice "boom goes my ship"8- Imagine 2 merchants, one wanting to sell lemons for $5 and another wanting to buy lemons for $10. Now imagine that they're physically sitting right next to each other. And no trading is occurring between them. Yes, this happens inside the game's stations. Even Fable was more realistic than this.9- Merchants have very limited stock. Want to buy 100 missiles? You'll have to talk to at least 5 merchant10- Every NPC looks identical. The only human in the entire universe that has hair is your co-pilot Ysha.X3 also had many flaws, but it was enjoyable and fun to play. This one? No. Everything you do feels like a chore.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2016
												I have changed my recommendation from recommended to not recommended.  I was unable to finish the campaign of the game without hacking my save file, because there of objectives presented in a campaign mission that were impossible to achieve; specifically, there is a mission that requires you to build a space station; to build that station you must purchase resources, and two resources I needed were made unavailable to me through vendors, side quests, resource farming or in-game piracy.  I cannot recommend a game with a single player campaign that is impossible to beat.The only way to beat the mission without hacking your save file is to know what resources you need ahead of time and acquire them before you reach the point in the campaign where you build a fleet and go to war with the controlling faction.  That is an unreasonable ask.  In addition, the general learning curve is far too steep, and available tutorials that explain all of the game mechanics are poor in the way they explain mechanics; lacking both detail and clarity, and difficult to find and repeat when needed.Really, there are a littany of small problems that detract from the overall enjoyment of this game; too many to list, but would include: poor fleet AI, frequent issues with object targeting while in your ship, a poor UI with multiple problems such as illegible fonts, an inability to recolor HUD elements (which is a problem when half of the galaxy is the same color orange as your targeting reticle) and object indicators that are way too small; a poorly implemented dialog wheel, the choice of using a sidecar menu for game interaction instead of superior and more popular radial menus, along with several others I don't care to mention for the sake of brevity.

content:
Posted: March 24, 2014
												Ok, I finally got the joystick working with this game, so now I've gotten a chance to actually play it (since I refuse to play flight/space sims without a joystick) it's actually a pretty good space sim, waaaayyy better than Elite Boredom, that game has nothing over this one other than graphics (the few it has). My main gripe against rebirth is that they limited you to one ship, I get why, but it's just ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. It is cool you can control multiple ships though. All in all it's shaping up to be a good game and performance is ~37 FPS Maxed out with 2xAA at 3840x2160 on my 780TIs; at 1920x1080p @144Hz I get 57 FPS average maxed out. I would recommend this game to anybody who is dismayed by the absolute lack of game in Elite Dangerous, that's why I revisited this one and I'm glad I did. It has way more substance, you can go into the space stations, hunt for minerals, trade, do bounties, do escort missions, capture ships, the list is pretty comprehensive. The graphics are still pretty darn good other than the character models. I actually found this game far more immersive than the dead world of ED. Now I've only got 4.4 hours in so far, so if I find anything untoward I will update this, but so far runs well and plays awesome.
